strIntroduction: This is an hour long double decker bus tour to see the most popular sites in Osaka. The bus has multi-lingual audio guide in English, Mandarin, Cantonese and Korean. There are two courses: North Course - Umeda Area Tour Ohatsu Tenjin Shrine – Tenroku - The Japan Mint - Osaka Castle - Osaka Museum of History - JR Osaka Station - River Station Hachikenya - Osaka City Central Public Hall Start times: 11:40, 13:20, 17:00, 18:20 South Course - Namba Area Tour. Ohatsu Tenjin Shrine – Midosuji – Namba - Denden Town – Tanimachi – Tsutenkaku - Abeno Harukasu - Shitennoji Temple - Umeda Sky Building Start times: 10:30, 14:40, 15:40, 19:20 For both courses, the tour starts and ends at JR Expressway Bus Terminal in Osaka Station, and the duration is approximately 1 hour. Please understand that this is NOT a hop-on, hop-off tour. You will only see the sights from the bus.

strIntroduction: Origami is an ancient traditional Japanese art of folding paper to make interesting and beautiful figures. In this two hour class you will learn about the history and culture of this unusual art and learn how to make several different kinds of shapes out of paper. You may choose to make the most classic famous Japanese Crane, which has become one of the symbols of Japan. There is a belief that if you make 1,000 Japanese cranes within a year, your wish will come true. That's why you can see bundles of thousands of colorful cranes called Senbazuru hanging at temples. However, origami is much more than that. There are thousands of figures you can make out of paper. In this class you will also learn how to make Kusudama - a star-like figure made of many smaller pieces of paper. The class is 2 hours long and can be started any time between 11 am and 3 pm. *Please choose the appropriate option when booking the tour. The price is per person, so if your group is 2 or more participants, please book the tour the according number of times.
strTitle: Enjoy an Origami Crafting Lesson in Nagoya

strIntroduction: We provide two options for this cooking class: Option 1: Japan Soul Food What do Japanese people eat at home on a typical day? Find out what the staple Japanese foods are and how to cook them home-style, with a local. During this class we will cook a standard lunch or dinner meal consisting of several simple but delicious dishes. Option 2: Nagoya Traditional Cuisine Did you know that every area in Japan has its own traditional regional foods? In Nagoya, people cherish their local dishes such as misokatsu – pork cutlet with red miso sause, tebasaki – deep-fried chicken wings, kishimen – flat noodles, tenmusu – riceball with cooked shrimp, and many others. During this class we will teach you how to make some of the most loved Nagoya foods like a real Nagoyajin! ALSO: Learn how to use red miso paste - the very Nagoyan ingredient and make dishes with it! BONUS: Visit a local supermarket with a guide and learn how it's different from the one in your country. *Please choose the appropriate option when booking the tour. The price is per person, so if your group is 2 or more participants, please book the tour the according number of times.
strTitle: Learn to Cook Traditional Nagoya Cuisine and More

strIntroduction: You will take a morning walk through sleepy Nagoya to Nagoya Fish Market and see freshly caught fish being sold and prepared for the restaurants and shops for the day. Founded over 100 years ago, the market has over 400 stalls and shops and provides seafood for the entire city. You will see giant Maguro (tuna) being sliced with huge swords and special machines, fugu (poisonous puffer-fish) being prepared by the professional cooks, and many other types of fish and seafood in all variety being sold. You will also be able to buy seafood and other goods such as pickles, seaweed, senbei (rice crackers), and much more. After the tour of the fish market, we will take you to the sushi restaurant nearby serving the fresh fish from the market, or we will buy fish at the market and head back to Nishiasahi guest house to enjoy a sushi cooking class, where the Master will teach you how to properly prepare and slice the fish and make perfect nigiri-zushi. After the cooking class you will be able to make great sushi anywhere, anytime. Without cooking class 7:00 meet at Nagoya Station, walk to the market 7:20 Arrive at the market and stroll around with your guide 8:00 eat breakfast 8:40 buy omiyage 9:00 end of the tour With cooking class 7:00 meet at Nagoya Station, walk to the market 7:20 Arrive at the market and stroll around with your guide, pick up fish 8:00 walk to Nishiasahi 8:15 start cooking 9:00 breakfast 9:30 end of the tour *Please choose the appropriate option when booking the tour. The price is per person, so if your group is 2 or more participants, please book the tour the according number of times.
strTitle: Join a Nagoya Yanagibashi Fish Market tour with Sushi

strIntroduction: Enjoy a fine meal at a traditional style Japanese restaurant in the company of two charming Maiko and Geiko, and their musician. Geiko and Maiko, who are considered walking pieces of art, are Japanese female entertainers who dance, play games, and entertain guests at a banquet. The Maiko will perform some of their most popular dances, including the Nagoya’s favourite Shachihoko dance (that you can see only in Nagoya), just for you and your friends. You can play some games with Maiko, ask them questions, take pictures together, or even challenge the Shachihoko performance yourself! This is a unique opportunity to experience both traditional Japanese stage performances and eat a multi-dish kaiseki meal in a splendid restaurant with rich history and classical atmosphere. On this tour you will meet your guide-interpreter and go to a gorgeous Japanese-style restaurant located in the city's former samurai residence. Many of these restaurants are difficult to book and enter, but you will have the unique chance to relish the taste of a delicious multi-dish kaiseki lunch or dinner in a classical atmosphere specially during the event. *Please choose the appropriate option when booking the tour. The price is per person, so if your group is 2 or more participants, please book the tour the according number of times.
strTitle: Banquet with Nagoya Geisha and Traditional Lunch or Dinner

Finally, you will have pictures taken by a professional photographer in a photo studio. strIntroduction: Furoshiki skill will revolutionize the way you wrap presents for your dear ones: forget the wrapping paper and instead use a beautiful handkerchief, which can make a great present on its own. Furoshiki features many different ways to wrap a present of any shape and size. The art of furoshiki does not only provide a beautifully and originally wrapped present – the wrapping itself makes a wonderful present and can be used in the future by the receiver for many purposes. We will start the tour at Fushimi station and head to a nearby shop for furoshiki fabric shopping. Here you will be able to buy many sheets of any fabric you like. After shopping we will go to Nishiasahi and have the class. strIntroduction: Japan can be a challenging destination, especially for first-time visitors. We would like to help you have an enjoyable and smooth trip in this beautiful country. In this two hour session we will help you to plan through your travel itinerary, give some advice on places to visit, explain about transportation and any other aspects of travel you might want to know. You will also be provided with the basic most important vocabulary and kanji list and explained about certain cultural differences and local etiquette rules to avoid any awkward situation. Finally, end the session with a short tour of Endoji shopping street. *Please choose the appropriate option when booking the tour. The price is per person, so if your group is 2 or more participants, please book the tour the according number of times.

strIntroduction: On this tour in Nagoya you will meet a local manga artist who will teach you the skills of drawing Digital manga using special software, or the manga school manager who will give you tips on boosting your existing skills on paper if you already practice the art. If you do not specify the type of class, we will book the paper tools teaching class with school manager due to limited availability of Digital class with the mangaka. You will learn how to use tools to draw manga such as G-pen, screen tone, etc. Practice drawing and get feedback from a real manga art professional. We recommend booking 2 weeks ahead of time due to limited availability. This tour normally holds 1-3 guests, but can hold up to 4 guests if necessary. PLEASE NOTE: Manga artist as a instructor If a student wants to have a real professional manga artist as an instructor, they need to take "digital manga class (draw manga with a computer) " that is held 1-2 times a month. Same price as the basic manga class. If clients have more than three people, we can ask for a special class just for them. Please inquire about the schedule and availability one month prior. The class is 2 hours long. However, we allow extra time for transportation to the class facility from the meeting place. Meeting place is either Nagoya station or Manekineko at Osu (recommended).
strTitle: Take a Manga drawing class in Nagoya

strIntroduction: Enjoy winter activities in Hokkaido by making a reservation for this JR Day Trip Ski Pack with your family and friends! There are three different destinations for this JR Day Trip Ski Pack, which are Tomamu, Sahoro, and Niseko. All destinations include the round trip JR train ticket (for Tomamu and Sahoro, the train tickets are designated in advance), 1 day ticket for lift & gondola, and rental ski set (skis, poles, and boots). The ski resorts for each destinations are Hoshino Resort Tomamu, Sahoro Resort, and Niseko Hirafu or Niseko Village Ski Resort. Except for Niseko Village Ski Resort, the plan includes the round trip JR train ticket, Niseko Village Ski Lift and Gondola 8 hour ticket, lunch, hot springs, and does not include the rental ski sets. The Tomamu Ski Resort has a lot of bells and whistles that make it incredibly family friendly. The resort is the most extravagant in Hokkaido, as it has 50 meters wave pool, glamorous restaurants, and peculiar looking sky-scraper hotel towers. The ski courses suite to all levels of skiers, so everyone can enjoy skiing at this resort. The resort is also friendly to kids, as it has an adventure terrain park and kids-specific park. The amenities and infrastructures of this resort is top notch. Sahoro Resort in Hokkaido is a reasonably small to medium sized with only 17 courses that suite all levels of skiers. The lifts are well developed with a gondola, 2 high speed quads, and 5 other lifts. The slopes of Sahoro are uncrowded, although sometimes the lift queues can develop at the gondola if there are a lot of local school kids. This resort offers various other activities during winter such as evening grooming tours, fishing, snow shoe tours (3 hours), snow rafting behind a snowmobile, snow field horseback trekking (30 or 50 minutes rides), and tubing and sledding. Niseko Grand Hirafu Village is a cultural mountain paradise in Hokkaido. The village is internationally recognized for amazing snowfalls, great skiing, snowboarding and a long winter season, which make Hirafu is truly a unique ski town. You can also enjoy world class dining, relaxing hot springs, bars and events at this resort too. Niseko Village Ski Resort sits within the Niseko United ski area, that accesses inter-linked ski resorts boasting a combined 2,191 acres of skiable terrain. The resort is strategically located at the base of Mount Niseko Annupuri and it offers the award-winning hotels with spa and hot spring facilities, a dining and retail village hub, luxury residences, and international snow school and alpine activities. The restaurant is open from 11:30 to 14:30, and the hot springs is open from 13:00. The lunch is either buffet or set menu. Bath and face towels are included in the plan too. The Itinerary for each destination is as follows: For Tomamu - Departing from Sapporo Station to Tomamu Station with Limited Express Super Tokachi (designated train) - Departing from Tomamu Station to Hoshino Resort Tomamu with shuttle bus - Spend time at Hoshino Resort Tomamu - Departing from Hoshino Resort Tomamu to Tomamu Station with shuttle bus - Departing from Tomamu Station to Sapporo Station with Limited Super Express Tokachi (designated train). For Sahoro - Departing from Sapporo Station to Shintoku Station with Limited Express Super Tokachi (designated train) - Departing from Shintoku Station to Sahoro Resort with shuttle bus - Spend time ant Sahoro Resort - Departing from Sahoro Resort to Shintoku Station with shuttle bus - Departing from Shintoku Station to Sapporo Station with Limited Super Express Tokachi (designated train). For Niseko Grand Hirafu - Departing from Sapporo Station to Otaru Station with local or rapid train - Departing from Otaru Station to Kutchan Station with local train - Departing from Kutchan Station to Niseko Grand Hirafu with local bus (Niseko bus) - Spend time at Niseko Grand Hirafu - Departing from Niseko Grand HIrafu to Kutchan Station with local bus (Niseko bus) - Departing from Kutchan Station to Otaru Station with local train - Departing from Otaru Station to Sapporo Station with local or rapid train - Schedule for the local bus departing to or from Kutchan Station is as follows: Kutchan Station 7:55 → Hirafu Welcome Center 8:13 Kutchan Station 9:40 → Hirafu Welcome Center 9:58 Kutchan Station 13:00 → Hirafu Welcome Center 13:18 Hirafu Welcome Center 13:30 → Kutchan Station 13:48 Hirafu Welcome Center 15:42 → Kutchan Station 16:00 Hirafu Welcome Center 16:07 → Kutchan Station 16:25 Hirafu Welcome Center 17:30 → Kutchan Station 17:48 Hirafu Welcome Center 18:48 → Kutchan Station 19:06 For Niseko Village Ski Resort - Departing from Sapporo Station to Otaru Station with local or rapid train - Departing from Otaru Station to Kutchan Station with local train - Departing from Kutchan Station to Niseko Village Ski Resort with shuttle bus - Spend time at Niseko Village Ski Resort - Departing from Niseko Village Ski Resort to Kutchan Station with shuttle bus - Departing from Kutchan Station to Otaru Station with local train - Departing from Otaru Station to Sapporo Station with local or rapid train

strIntroduction: Make a reservation for Kiroro Ski Resort and enjoy your winter by skiing at one of the best ski park in Japan! Kiroro Ski Resort is located approximately 43 km west of Sapporo Hokkaido, approximately a 90 minutes by car from Chitose Airport and 60 minutes by car from Niseko. Kiroro Ski Resort offers ski school service, a snow park for children, snow shoe tours, and snow cat tours. Kiroro is a child friendly ski resort, as it is equipped with a day car “Kids Room” available when the mountain center is open, and a day nursery (available everyday) making it a great ski resort for the family. Compare to other ski resorts in Hokkaido, Kiroro Ski Resort is less well known, but it has the most modern and newest facilities and infrastructures. In addition, this resort is also lack of crowds and has well established Kids club, making it perfect for the families. The resort has 21 runs suited to all levels including beginner, intermediate, and advanced with fantastic snow powder running throughout the trees. In addition, there are also mogul courses and a basic terrain park. The facilities and services at Kiroro resort are well organized with a modern lift system. If you do not wish to ski or snowboard, Kiroro Ski Resort offers you other services such as indoor and open hot springs, swimming pool and day spa inside the resort building, snow cat sightseeing tours, snow shoe tours, sledding, and snow tubing. Kiroro Ski Resort also has games arcade with billiards and pachinko. This tour package offers you both the admission ticket for the ski park and the transportation. As for transportation, it has several options that you can choose as follows: Private taxi transfer to or from Sapporo (2-4 people) Private taxi transfer to or from Sapporo (5-9 people) Shared bus transfer to or from Sapporo Ski & Snowboard rental for private taxi transfer Ski & Snowboard rental for shared bus Private taxi transfer to or from Chitose Airport (2-4 people, optional) Private taxi transfer from Chitose Airport to Sapporo (2-4 people, optional) Private taxi transfer from Sapporo to Chitose Airport (2-4 people, optional) Private taxi transfer to or from Chitose Airport (5-9 people, optional) Private taxi transfer from Chitose Airport to Sapporo (5-9 people, optional) Private taxi transfer from Sapporo to Chitose Airport (5-9 people, optional)
strTitle: Reservation for a Ski Tour at Kiroro Ski Resort in Hokkaido!

strIntroduction: Make a reservation for Sapporo Kokusai Skiing Resort and enjoy your winter by skiing at one of the best ski park in Japan! Sapporo Kokusai Skiing Resort is located within Jozankei Onsen hot spring area near Sapporo, and it attracts not only local skiers but also many repeaters from outside Hokkaido. The resort has a lot of amount of snow and many courses for all level of skiers, even though it is located very close to the cities (within 60 and 40-minute drive from Sapporo and Otaru, approximately). This resort is very popular among skiers, as they can ski at this park until the Golden Week holiday season in May every year. The main attraction of this resort is the Sky Cabin gondolas, which each car is capable to carry eight skiers at once. The Merchen Daiichi lift also available here and it can carry four skiers at once. A 3.6-kilometer Rinkan Course-Marchen Course offers exhilarating and satisfying glade skiing in the wildness. This course is a perfect course for all level of skiers, even entry-level skiers can enjoy skiing safely. There are seven courses such as the Downhill course for advanced skiers, Swing course for intermediate skiers and Woody course for beginners. Each slope is wide and long, enabling skiers to enjoy skiing in accordance with their levels. This tour package offers you both the admission ticket for the ski park and the transportation. As for transportation, it has several options that you can choose from as follows: - Private taxi transfer to or from Sapporo (2-4 people) - Private taxi transfer to or from Sapporo (5-9 people) - Shared bus transfer to or from Sapporo - Ski & Snowboard rental for private taxi transfer - Ski & Snowboard rental for shared bus - Private taxi transfer to or from Chitose Airport (2-4 people, optional) - Private taxi transfer from Chitose Airport to Sapporo (2-4 people, optional) - Private taxi transfer from Sapporo to Chitose Airport (2-4 people, optional) - Private taxi transfer to or from Chitose Airport (5-9 people, optional) - Private taxi transfer from Chitose Airport to Sapporo (5-9 people, optional) - Private taxi transfer from Sapporo to Chitose Airport (5-9 people, optional)
strTitle: Reserve a Tour for Sapporo Kokusai Skiing Resort, Hokkaido!

strIntroduction: Explore Hakone at your pace with the Hakone freepass independent package tour. The pass includes a one way ticket to Hakone on the Odakyu Romance car departing from Shinjuku station. In Hakone, you'll have access to most of local transportation to visit Hakone's best spots to admire Mt. Fuji like Hakone Tozan or Hakone pirate ship. Since there is no scheduled itinerary or guide, you can explore Hakone at your own pace, and decide what sights to visit. When you get hungry, head to Nanakamado for a traditional Japanese lunch (included in the price). The pass also includes discounts for over 50 facilities including museums and other tourists attractions. You can also stop at Gotemba Premium Outlet for a little bit of shopping before getting back to Tokyo by bus. Make the most out of your trip to Hakone with the Hakone freepass!
strTitle: Explore the best of Hakone with a one day package pass

strIntroduction: A great time and money-saver, this tour will allow you to visit some of Kyoto's famous places all from the comfort of a beautiful double-decker bus. This bus is an open Top SKY BUS which allows you to feel the breeze and atmosphere of Kyoto. With so many different sites to choose from, it can be hard to decide where to go, so leave it up to us as we take you through a stress-free, hassle-free tour of one of the most famous cities in the world. The places we will visit are as follows: - Kinkakuji Temple Also known as the famous "Temple of the Golden Pavilion," Kinkakuji Temple is one of the most iconic and famous sites in Kyoto. Gold leaf, which is gold hammered into thin sheets, covers the outside of the first two floors. The temple is particularly unique in that each floor is built in a different architectural style. - Kiyomizudera Temple Built in 778, Kiyomizudera Temple one of Japan's great World Heritage Sites. 139 cedar poles hold up this great structure, which allow visitors a fantastic view of the city. Kiyomizu means pure water, and many people come to this temple to wish for wealth, success in love, and a long life. Schedule (morning tour): 10:00 Meeting at Kyoto Station Karasuma Bus Terminal - Nishihonganji Temple - Nijo Castle - Seimei Shrine - Kitano Tenmangu - Kinkakuji Temple (40 minutes) - Daitokuji Temple - Reizei House - Kyoto Gardens - Kamocho Bridge - Lake Biwa Canal - Heian Shrine - Shorenin Temple - Chionin Temple - Yasaka Shrine - Kiyomizudera Temple (70 minutes) - Kyoto Tower 14:30 Tour ends at Kyoto Station Karasuma Bus Terminal. Schedule (afternoon tour): 13:00 Meeting at Kyoto Station Karasuma Bus Terminal - Nishihonganji Temple - Nijo Castle - Seimei Shrine - Kitano Tenmangu - Kinkakuji Temple (40 minutes) - Daitokuji Temple - Reizei House - Kyoto Gardens - Kamocho Bridge - Lake Biwa Canal - Heian Shrine - Shorenin Temple - Chionin Temple - Yasaka Shrine - Kiyomizudera Temple (70 minutes) - Kyoto Tower 17:30 Tour ends at Kyoto Station Karasuma Bus Terminal.
strTitle: Enjoy a Half Day Double-Decker Bus Tour of Kyoto!

strIntroduction: Indian culture and its textiles are interwoven. There is nothing quite like the insightful embrace of one of India's most respected and valued cultures - textiles. Come on a journey to meet textile craft communities in Gujarat and indulge in a rich, diverse cultural experience, complete with historical context, wrapped with local interactions and cuisine . This journey will be filled with new friendships, fonder appreciation and understanding on Indian textiles, and memories worth a thousand counts. Day 1: On arrival into Ahmedabad, India’s historical cradle otherwise known as the `Tortoise's Back‘ we head straight to check into Diwan’s Bungalow , (time permitting) else head straight for a curated walk around the world-renowned Calico Museum of Textiles archiving textiles from the Mughal and Provincial Courts with a display of intricate dyeing, weaving, printing and embroidery techniques from across India. Late lunch at Swati Snacks, where a quick bite must include panki and sugar cane juice or thaleepeeth, and khichu cooked to spiced perfection! Post this we head to meet Villo Mirza , who has done some pioneering work with craft and textiles for SEWA for many years and now runs her own trust working with women on applique and patchwork based design. We return to our boutique hotel and refresh ourselves before we head to a sit down dinner at Agaashiye , at the charming House of MG, where we enjoy the cool evening breeze and indulge in their special Khansa Thali. A long day draws to an end as we get some much needed shut eye. Day 2: This morning we take a her;itage walk in the old city, including exploring old havelis and rani no hajeero, the quintessential amdavaadi market. Lunch is at the Green house café, followed by a quick stop over at Art Book Centre, to meet Manohar bhai who will wax eloquent about the best books ever written on Indian textiles and sell you some in the bargain offering a deal sweeter than basundi. Straight after this we head to meet the Chitaras, a handful of artists that still make hand painted Pachedis- a kalamkari art form traditional to Gujarat. In olden times, the Harijan community or the lower castes, often labeled untouchables, did not have access to temples. Made on cotton or silk fabric, hand painted Pachedis worked as their own personal shrines that were used for worship of the Goddess. Time permitting a visit to Bandhej to meet Archana Shah author of ‘Shifting Sands’ documenting decades of her work with craftsmen and women of Gujarat. An interaction with her at the store and we leave for the evening at Vishaala. No trip to Ahmedabad is complete without a trip to Vishaala to savour Gujarati hospitality at its best. Bursting at the seams, we come back to Diwan’s and retire for the night. Day 3: Packed breakfast in tow we have a very early start to this day as we drive out of Ahmedabad to Bhuj, the textile centre within the Kutch District in Gujarat, approximately 299km away. Lunch with Jabbar bhai Khatri in Dhamadka followed by a demonstration of Ajrakh, we spend some time at the printing unit and we’re on our way to visit Dr. Ismail Khatri, one of the masters in Ajrakh and a pioneer in the art . Ajrakh literally meant aaj ke din rakh, or 'keep it for today' because that is what the process is. At every stage of the tedious dying process, the fabric should dry for three to four days. Nature plays an important role in the making of Ajrakh. Craftsmen work in total harmony with their environment, where the sun, river, animals, trees and mud are all part of its making. A discussion on the Ajrak textiles at his workshop makes for engaging conversations over a reflective and relaxing cup of tea with the Khatris.. Drive back into Bhuj and before we wind up for the day we meet Ali Mohammed Isha, a textile intellectual who walks us through a tie-dyeing technique knows as Bandhani, a laborious all hand done tie-dye printing process. Tonite we dine at Prince, a traditional meal, and head back to our halt for the night, the Garha Safari Lodge. Its been a long day and we pack in early. Day 4: After exploring the property in the morning, and an early breakfast, we head to to Bhuj to meet an avid textile collector cum expert, and look at some of his collections dating back to the late 1800 and early 1900s, not just in the rabari embroidery styles but also the most exquisite phulkaris and kanthas. Food for the soul truly. Then we head to Bhujodi in the heart of Kutch where we spiral into discussions on traditional pit looms and shuttle looms and hear from Shyamji Vankar, about the challenges faced by the vankars known for their extra weft wool weaving . After our interactions, over lunch with the vankars, we make our way toward an interaction with the Rabari community known for their homes. Here we see the indigenous mud homes decorated by women, with a royal color sensibility and embedded with mirrors for a touch of local glamour. Dinner at a local eatery in Bhuj and we head back to the Lodge and retire for the night. Day 5: We check out of the Garha Safari Lodge and head to Shrujan. We check into their traditional bhungas, and meet the team at Shrujan who expose us to women craftsman working on sustaining the traditional embroidery of the Mochi Bharat (cobbler's stitch) and Rabari techniques unique to Gujarat. Lunch at Shrujan over inspiring interactions with Chandaben or Ami Shroff, the force behind Shrujan. Since it’s inception, Shrujan has supported hundreds of villages and brought the region worldwide recognition for its unimaginably beautiful embroidered textiles.In it’s work, Shrujan highlights 16 different embroidery styles each specific to a different tribe. Post lunch, we’re at Khamir, looking at other crafts that Kutch is also home to - wood, leather, pottery, and metal crafts. Later this afternoon, we watch extraordinary fabrics coming to life as the upholders of the single ikat patola tradition weave silk and cotton threads and then tie and dye them into works of art. Back to Shrujan for the evening, relax and assimilate all that you have seen these last 5 days. Day 6: A visit to Kala Raksha, in Sumarasar, as its name suggests, a grassroots enterprise committed to preserving the traditional arts and craft of Kutch, reveals the most exquisite hand embroidered and patch worked garments and accessories, and a collection of old costumes and embroideries which will take your breath away. A quick lunch at Sankalp and we head straight out to Dasada. Arrive in time for late dinner. Day 7: A 6:00 am morning is fit for a 2 hour safari. Around the Little Rann of Kutch, an Indian Wild Ass Sanctuary rich in biodiversity. After spotting some White- footed Desert Foxes, Striped Hyenas and Golden Jackal, we settle down for breakfast before checking out. A quick stop over at the Sun Temple in Modhera and a visit to Patan’s Step Well, a storage system using steps to reach the water despite high or low water levels, often covered and a curious architectural interest. Lunch enroute at some place, and we drive on to Ahmedabad and straight to the airport for our flights back.
strTitle: Following the Thread - A Textile Trail in Gujarat

strIntroduction: Experience the intensity of the Walled City and unravel its rich history! The Shah Jahan Tour is the classic recipe for an exhilarating glimpse into the life and times of the great Mughal Emperor, Shah Jahan and the 1500 acre expanse of his capital - Shahjahanabad. At the time of its construction in the 17th Century, it was arguably the most prosperous and beautiful city in the world. Today, when you pass through its four hundred year old web of alleys held together with great big meshes of electric cables and infused with the smell of brewing tea and simmering breakfast curry, you see a mind boggling co-existence of the past and the future, competing for your attention. Emerging from this rainforest, thick with traditional architecture- typical of Shah Jahan’s time, you will find yourself in a Delhi of another time while you also see the Red Fort, Jama Masjid, the Spice Market and tranquil Civil Lines, the former British colonial area as a sharp contrast to hectic Old Delhi.
strTitle: Cycle through Old Delhi: The Shah Jahan Tour

strIntroduction: The Dharavi slum is a breathtaking, overwhelming experience in the heart of Mumbai, with a massive recycling industry, ultra-dense housing, and both poverty and wealth existing in close proximity. This tour will take you through the proud and industrious area of Dharavi. You will be able to see where people work, where people live and where people relax. We will show you the vast industrial areas with many important industries like the bakeries serving the whole of Mumbai. We will show you the residential areas where whole families live in a small room, local schools and even the pottery industries. If you are expecting extreme poverty and despair based on movie depictions, you will be disappointed. In fact this tour actively breaks stereotypical depictions of slums. Some of the areas will be familiar if you have seen the film ‘Slumdog Millionaire’ as much of the film was shot in Dharavi. Slumdog Millionaire Official Page: http://www.foxsearchlight.com/slumdogmillionaire/
strTitle: An Inside Look at the Slums of Mumbai: Dharavi

strIntroduction: The Different and ‘out of the ordinary’ Mumbai tour. It is a city of crazy contradictions – cheek by jowl, at once the commercial capital of India and also ‘home‘ to the homeless and poor migrant workers. After a heavy dose of history – palaces, forts and religions – temples, churches, Mumbai is refreshingly different and ‘offbeat’. You can visit diverse parts of the ‘living city’ where you experience a blast of color (sarees and flags), smells (fishy and spicy-masalas) and sounds, all amidst the broadest ‘smiles’ that merge with ‘sweat’ that trickles down their faces!
strTitle: Discover the Offbeat Side of Mumbai

strIntroduction: The aim of this walk is not to "visit", nor to make poverty a "tourist tour", but to meet people and exchange experiences with them, chatting over a cup of tea. The walk in the suburbs is much more than a walk, but an exchange, and a first step towards awareness. This activity also allows slum dwellers, if they wish, to interact with foreigners from different cultures, and showcase their daily life. This once in a life time opportunity will be a guided tour where a guide from the slum will show you around the alleys of his slum for 2 hours. He will show you how over 40 thousand people living in from diffrent communities. While in the slum, you'll interact and have traditional tea with a family during which they can share their personal story of survival and life in the slums. This walk is run to support PETE (Providing Education To Everyone), and 80 percent of the money out of profits after tax of the tour will go to the organization.
strTitle: Learn about Life in Delhi's Slums with a Local

strIntroduction: Come on a journey with me and take a peek into the world of block printing, starting with my collection of exquisite hand blocks acquired over a period of time and continuing onto a hands-on immersive workshop with a modern-day block printer still using traditional motifs. This special art nurtures your understanding of the printing technique that is a part of India’s contemporary textile culture. As your eyes fixate on the intricate sharpness of every carving, you get sensitized to the painstaking time and effort involved in each stage of the production process. This introductory workshop will introduce you to the history and art of block printing that have emerged through the years in different geographies in South Asia, and the tools needed. We follow the different stages in the printing process, with the help of swatches – from grey cloth to the final finished product. After a quick demo, you get to craft your own personalized creation by choosing from a variety of designs on wooden blocks, and a range of colors. Bring along a t-shirt or a scarf or just simple napkins, paper or textile - anything that you want to print on. Most importantly, don't forget an open mind raring to experiment! Working with me will allow you to develop a fuller appreciation and outlook into a world filled with color, seeped in tradition and old-world techniques. Color your hands with the reminisces of blues, pinks and reds after testing your skills at hand block printing with pigment, each offering a cultivated experience into the diversity in textiles. Get an interactive, hands-on experience - come Breakaway
strTitle: Learn Block Printing at a Workshop in Mumbai

strIntroduction: If you want to hike, experience the nature, ancient heritage, tribal art and culture in one place, then Kotagiri is your obvious choice. Kotagiri is a small town in the Nilgiri district of Tamilnadu. It is situated at an altitude of 2200 meters above the sea level, and is only 20 kms from Ooty (Ootacamund) and 75 Kms from Coimbatore. It is the home to tribes such as Kurumbas, Todas, Irulas, Kotas and Paniyas. Kotagiri is a hiker's paradise with endless trails. This area is also very rich in wildlife, the Indian Gaur can be spotted grazing in the wooded areas, and the other animals that thrive here are leopards, spotted deer, and wild boar. This is a 2 days trip with one night stay in a dormitory in a tea estate. Upon the arrival at Coimbatore, participants will be taken on a private vehicle to our campsite in Kotagiri. It is approximately a 2.30 hours drive. After refreshment and breakfast, you will be visiting Banagudi Shola - the sacred grove of the Kurumba tribes in the first day morning. Walk through the banagudi shola and visit the dolmens and the community’s centuries old places of worship. This shola patch is a bird watcher’s paradise where you can see the bird species endemic to Nilgiris biosphere. Post lunch at our campsite walk to the Catherine waterfalls and drench yourself in the cold water. The day ends with campfire and dinner. The second day starts with hot tea and a nature walk to the breathtaking view of kallar valley. After breakfast, you would visit Bikkapathymund – a Toda tribal hamlet. It would take approximately 1.30 hours hike to reach the tribal hamlet. You can talk to the village elders about their traditions and see the women doing embroidery works (for which they are known for). You will be served packed lunch. Post lunch you will trek back to reach the starting point. The trip ends with shopping at the “Green shop” where you could buy fair trade & tribal produces, and you will be dropped at Coimbatore.
strTitle: Trek, Bird Watch, and Experience the Nature of the Nilgiris

strIntroduction: Charles II wasn’t sure where his wedding gift was located and he didn’t really care too much for it. So when the British East India Company approached him for possession of the islands he was more than happy to lease them to the Company. By 1668 all seven islands of Bombay were under the control of the British East India Company and thus began the herculean task of developing the Company’s newest asset. After completing the task of fortifying the town from sea borne invasion the next job at hand was to stamp their authority on the local inhabitants and what better way to do so than by constructing buildings that epitomised might, authority, imperialism and power. Soon structures began popping up all over the ‘new’ town to serve some purpose or the other. A Cathedral to pray in, Town Hall to conduct civic activities, a University to educate, a mammoth station that is the finest creation of the architect F.W. Stevens and, most notably, an archway to commemorate the visit of their Imperial Majesties. It was under the guidance of great British Governors like Lord Mountstuart Elphinstone that the arts were promoted and scholarly debate was established. Welcome to the ‘Churchgate and Heritage Mile’ walk. This walk takes you into the heart of the old ‘Fort’. Explore the ‘White Town’ or the European half of the old town that existed within the Fort walls. Begin the walk at F.W.Steven’s gothic masterpiece, the grand Chatrapati Shivaji Terminus also known as the Victoria Terminus. Then walk down D.N.Road, also called the Heritage Mile of Mumbai, while admiring one of the oldest parts of the city(almost as old as the city itself) which even today is reminiscence of it colonial past and make your way to the ornate Flora Fountain. Here take a minute to soak in the atmosphere of one of the busiest precincts’ of Mumbai. Next just a hop, skip and jump away lies the historic art district of Kala Ghoda with its many Gothic buildings and numerous art galleries creating a charm that is unmatched in Mumbai. Move onto the Oval Maidan where in a great phalanx lie the Old Secretariat, University Library and Convocation Hall, High Court building , the old PWD building and Telegraph Department, a truly imperial vision like a fleet of massive stone battleships, monolithic, awe-inspiring and supremely self confident. Once they faced out across the sea in silent tribute to the naval power that built them. As a group they coalesce to form an impressively romantic skyline and they bequeathed an identity and style to the city that is unique to Mumbai. Finally take Veer Nariman Road (the former Churchgate Street) down to Marine Drive to enjoy a fantastic view of the Art Deco Skyline that has become an identity of Mumbai the world over.
strTitle: Walk through the Historic Heart of Mumbai

strIntroduction: Ladakh is often seen as a last frontier by travellers. Once upon a time it was on the crucial trade route between Central Asia and China. Remnants of those influences can still be seen across Ladakh. Today, the region is politically important having borders with both Pakistan and China. Culturally it is rich with the varied influences coming through. Ladakh is also where the Indus originates – the river that gives India its name. Summer is when the most festivals take places in Ladakh and the visitors pour in to get a glimpse of this unique landscape. Tourism forms an important part of the economy of this harsh land. PAGIR is a group of people with disabilities and their families who are working for improved livelihoods for those like themselves. They wanted to move away from viewing people with disabilities as charitable cases and get into the mainstream economy of tourism. And that is how Himalaya on Wheels emerged. It is a holiday that lets you spend a day with a Ladakhi family if you like. It also has activities for guests with mobility issues. Day 1 – Reach Leh and rest in the hotel to acclimatize to the high altitude. It takes about a day to get used to the lower oxygen at this high altitude. There is no correlation between age, sex, physical fitness and high altitude sickness (HAS). So it is best to relax the first day. If you have any symptoms such as headache, nausea, hallucinations, do speak to our team and they will get you medical help. The doctors in Leh are well trained to handle HAS. Often the solution is as simple as giving oxygen or moving to a lower altitude. Day 2 – We head west towards the Sham Valley. On the way we will stop at the Gurudwara Patthar Sahib, the Indus-Zanskar Confluence and the Alchi Monastery, the oldest in the region. At night, we will stop at the Uley Tokpo resort. Set amongst orchards, it gives you a view of the Indus flowing way below its cliff. Day 3 – you have the choice of trekking upto a nearby village before lunch or heading back to Leh. If the latter, we will stop at the Likir monastery, SECMOL and the Hall of Fame Museum. SECMOL is an NGO working on social issues of the region. They will share with us their work around educational reforms and passive solar heating. The Museum has been set up by the Army and traces the history of the region. You spend the night in Leh. Day 4 – We can start as late as you want as today is spend in and around Leh – Shanti Stupa, Shey Gompa, Choglamsar – monasteries around Leh. Choglamsar is a Tibetan settlement relatively untouched by tourism. The monks here are open to discussions if you are interested. You could also choose to spend the day with a Ladakhi family, helping them with their work and maybe learn to cook their food. This is optional, so please let us know beforehand. Day 5 – Head to Pangong Lake stopping at Sindu Darshan on the way. You will cross the Changla pass, the third highest motorable road in the world. Spend the night by the Pangong Lake. Day 6 – Wake up early to catch the sun rise and just laze around by the Lake. Head back to Leh by around 10.00 am. Meet with your hosts, the PAGIR team, who operate the Himalaya on Wheels itinerary for Travel Another India. PAGIR – People’s Action Group for Inclusion and Rights – are a group of people with disabilities and their families who are working to improve their livelihoods and make Leh cleaner through their waste to craft programme. Himalaya on Wheels was set up by them since they wanted to move away from charity to getting a slice of the main economy of Ladakh which is tourism. You can visit their shop, Junkgwa Shrunkyob, later in the Leh market. Day 7 – Time to leave and send us your beautiful photos and travelogues.
strTitle: Visit the Breathtaking "Plateau of the World": Leh-Ladakh

strIntroduction: Located in Central India's Bundelkhand region, the village guest house is about 3 km from Chanderi, famous for its silks. Visit the village and let the rhythm of the looms create magic for your eyes and ears while you interact with weavers and design your own drape. The more adventurous could try their hand at weaving. Watch village life or visit the historic city of Chanderi while its past is unravelled brick by brick. Enjoy the folk tales hidden in the heart of Bundelkhand and surrender to folk music and lively dances of another India! Amraee will rejuvenate you with its earthiness and historic charm. The Amraee Guest House was set up as part of a UNDP and Government of India project to promote rural tourism. It was formally inaugurated in 2008 and open to guests since September 2011. The Pranpur Village Tourism Development Committee maintains and runs the guest house. Its main aim is to promote the weavers, potters and metal workers while developing the village as a tourist site. You can directly interact with the local craftspeople and buy products from them, ensuring maximum revenue to them and recognition of their skills. The guesthouse itself is set in a 5-acre mango orchard. Amraee derives its name from Aam (mangoes) and Raee (a Bundelkhandi folk dance). The house is built in traditional Bundelkhandi style architecture - all the four rooms are spacious, clean and comfortable with western style bathrooms attached. Experiences • Take a walk around the village and interact with artisans • Try your hand at turning a pot or weaving • Satiate your taste buds with Bundelkhandi thali • See (and join in) the Bundelkhandi folk dance Raee and Sehra • Enjoy a Bullock-cart ride • Visit the fields and participate in farming activities • Go shopping! Within 2 hours • Chanderi (3 km) - A small historic town with many monuments and home to Chanderi fabric • Monuments at Chanderi have been lovingly restored and maintained by the Scindia Foundation • Chanderi Museum (5 km) - A well maintained museum • Rajghat Dam (10 km) - One of the biggest dams in India, lovely place to see sunrise • Nanon (28 km) - A scenic place on the banks of river Urvashi, famous for pre-historic rock paintings • Kadwaya (60 km) - A cluster of temples, also known as mini-Khajuraho • Deogarh (72 km) - Ruins of Jain temples in the middle of a forest by the side of Betwa river
strTitle: Visit a Rural Village & Learn the Art of the Silk Handloom

strIntroduction: The cuisine of India is famous for the variety that it offers. Influences of the various dynasties that ruled this country and use of the local ingredients and spices have created a spectacular cuisine in each part of the country. The same is true even of Hyderabad which borrowed heavily from the Persians and Mughals, added the local flavours and evolved a distinctive cuisine. One of the most popular dishes of this cuisine is Biryani. Technically speaking, it is just a dish of rice and meat cooked with some spices but it evokes the most passionate emotions among many foodies. A good part of the Indian lifetime is spent hotly debating about which the best Biryani and wondering about its origins. This tour will reveal the delectable path that this dish has taken across the different parts of India. On this tour, we will also enjoy a sumptuous meal with one of the traditional families in Hyderabad.
strTitle: Discover and Taste Biryani with a Traditional Family

strIntroduction: One of the most remarkable features of the Khasi hills are the sacred forests, which have been preserved by traditional religious sanction since the ancient days. Trekking in the Abode of Clouds, Meghalaya is an experience will surely rejuvenate your senses like never before. Experience the misty blue hills with unique cultural experiences, great food and stunning campsites. We are proud to offer you this thrilling trip that will take you from rivers to caves, from the midst of broom forest to picturesque valleys. In this trek we take you to explore living root bridges, caves, mountain streams and other hidden treasures of Meghalaya. Come and experience the Khasi hospitality, camping at one of the most remote villages in Meghalaya. === Detailed Itinerary === Day 1 (5-6 Hours) We drive to Khrang, a remote village in the Cherrapunjee road from Guwahati via the picturesque hill station of Shillong. We start trekking from Khrang to Mawshuit and set up our base camp there. Have a cultural night at Mawshuit with traditional Khasi dance followed by an interaction with the locals. Learn about the Khasi way of life in this small but beautiful village set up in midst of green valleys covered with broom plantations and natural flora and fauna.. Overnight stay in tents. Day 2 (6-7 Hours) We start early and trek through the subtropical forest to reach to the magnificient living~root bridge 500 feet above the Wah Muor. Experience the thrill of trekking through thick forest and the old (now abandoned) market trail. Proceed downwards to Wah Muor and enjoy the crystal clear water in the heart of the forest. Proceed further to our next destination the caves. Trek to Krem (cave) Mawlynghoh and experience the thrill of exploring a virgin cave. Trek back to the village through the sub tropical forest crossing beautiful streams and valleys on the Way. Overnight stay in tents. Day 3 (6-7 Hours) After breakfast start trekking for Wah (river) Sohkhain and Wah Muru. Learn the traditional way of fishing and even catch a fish if lucky. Trek back to the village walking along the river. Relax at campsite with bonfire and music. Day 4 (5-6 Hours) Trek back to Khrang and drive back to Guwahati. Trip ends. * Program Schedule and routes are subject to change without prior notice (in unfavourable circumstances). * A11 guests are advised to get their travel insurance done before any adventure trip.
strTitle: Trek through the Sacred Forests of Meghalaya

strIntroduction: Home to the colorful and vibrant Naga tribe, Dzukou valley is branded as one of the most fascinating valleys of Nagaland. Also known as 'The Valley of Flowers', it is situated at an altitude of 2134 meters behind the Japhu ranges in the Eastern Himalayas. Different varieties of flowers from lilies to rhododendrons bloom during the monsoon giving the valley a carpet of flowers.The Dzukou valley offers one of the most captivating spots for bird-watching and trekking in Nagaland round the year. Duration: 5 days Grade: Easy Max elevation: 3014 meters This trek has two itineraries. You can chose between the 5-day itinerary that includes Japhu Peak ( 2nd highest peak in Nagaland) and the 3 day trip that includes Dzukou valley only. Detailed Itinerary: Day 1: Enchanting train ride from Guwahali, crossing rural villages and hills to reach Dimapur town by noon. Drive about 4 hours from Dimapur to the historic Khonoina village via Kohinm. Visit Khonoma fort and nearby villages, interact with locals and experience the Naga way of life. Camp overnight. Day 2: Start trekking and climb steadily for about 4 hours crossing a mountain into Dzukou valley. If lucky, you might spot the colourful Tragopan pheasant, the state bird of Nagaland. Explore the surrounding areas and camp overnight at the Ghost cave, locally know as the bhoot gufa. Day 3: Get up early and drive to Vishwema village and then trek to the base of Japhu peak and camp there overnight. Explore villages and nearby areas and also visit the tallest Rhododendron tree in the world (109 foot) in Japfu range. Day 4: We start early morning and reach Japhu peak after a steep climb to watch the breathtaking sunrise from the top. Witness amazing views of entire Naggaland and surrounding valleys from the peak. After spending some time at the peak we descend through the same route and reach Vishwema and then drive out to the beautiful hill station of Kohima. local sightseeing, in Kohima and overnight stay at hotel. Day 5: We drive to Dimapur and take a train ride back to Guwahati.
strTitle: Trek The Valley of Flowers & Take in the Beauty of Nagaland

strIntroduction: What is a home stay? A home stay is not just bed and breakfast. It is staying with the Indian family. Being a guest of the family... getting a peek into the Indian household. Detailed Tour Itinerary DAY 1: Arrival in Sawantwadi Upon arrival at your home­stay in Sawantwadi, you will be warmly welcomed by your Indian host family with a traditional garland and tikka. Your hosts will then assist you with the registration procedure and show you to your room. Upon settling in you will be taken around the home­stay property and given the opportunity to meet and mingle with your host family. After getting to know one another you will have a delicious lunch together. After lunch you can rest for a while. After your afternoon tea, you can visit the palace and later take a walk in the market. In the evening you will enjoy another home cooked dinner and of course a truly relaxing nights’ sleep. DAY 2: Puppetry & Rangoli Design Workshop Wake up and enjoy the warmth of a home made Indian breakfast prepared caringly by your host family. Today morning you will spend time interacting with the rangoli artists. Rangoli is the art of designing with coloured powder. The artsist will take thru the journey on how the simple designing has undergone change over the period of time. Lunch will be at the home stay. After your meal you will head out to the Pinguli Art Gallery. This art complex aims to showcase, revive and promote a dying folk art tradition by creating a platform for the artist and his community to pursue the age old craft of puppetry and to open avenues for artistic and creative exchange with participants from across the globe. After a touring of the complex you can sit down and view an original puppet show by local artists. After the display, you will head back to your home­stay. In the evening you will be invited to dine with your host family and enjoy another succulent dinner. DAY 3: Dolphin Cruise Today early morning, you will be heading out for an exciting trip of dolphin watching! A boat will take you out into the deep see where you will soon be surrounded by beautiful dolphins. Spend the morning at sea before heading back to your home­stay for a flavourful Indian lunch and siesta. Evening at leisure. DAY 4: Departure from Sawantwadi Today you can sleep in and wake up to have a relaxed breakfast with your host family. After you finish your meal it will be time to pack up your belongings, say your goodbyes to your gracious host family and depart for your onward journey home, surely with many wonderful memories from your trip.
strTitle: Homestay Getaway: Puppet Shows and Dolphin Watching

strIntroduction: A 4 day package giving you a first­hand glimpse into the village life. Understand the pillars of an Indian village ­ the panchayat, the village temple, the village well and the village school. In the village, every community has its rightful place of existence. Join in this package and understand the social weave and its importance. Detailed Tour Itinerary DAY 1: Arrival in Sawantwadi Upon arrival at your home­stay in Sawantwadi, you will be warmly welcomed by your Indian host family with a traditional garland and tikka. Your hosts will then assist you with the registration procedure and show you to your room. Upon settling in you will be taken around the home­stay property and given the opportunity to meet and mingle with your host family. After getting to know one another you will have a delicious lunch together. After lunch you can rest for a while. After your afternoon tea, you can visit the Sawantwadi palace; if possible have an interaction with the Queen Mother, and later take a walk in the market. You will also visit the Chitari galli or the Artists lane. In the evening you will enjoy another home cooked dinner and of course a truly relaxing nights’ sleep. DAY 2: Village Ways Early morning, you will go on a Nature Trail in the Amboli Jungles. After the trail, breakfast will be in a traditional home stay nearby. Later back to your place of stay. Freshen up. Today morning you will spend time interacting with the rangoli artists. Rangoli is the art of designing with coloured powder. The artist will take thru the journey on how the simple designing has undergone change over the period of time. Lunch will be at the home stay. Post lunch you will be taken around the village. You will get to experience the various mechanisms that make a village function. You will meet the village headman and interact with him/her. You will also get the opportunity to interact with village self help groups. These groups are essentially for women to make them economically self sufficient. You will be visiting a self help group unit. Tea and refreshments will be served by the local village women. Later you will view a garland making demonstration. Evening you will head back to the home stay. DAY 3: Puppetry After breakfast, you will visit the Fruit Research station. Here you will get to see the varieties of fruits. On your way back to the home stay, you will visit the Cashew factory. Here you will see the cashew processing. You can also shop for cashews. Lunch at the home stay. After tea you can visit the Pinguli tribal Puppetry village. Enjoy the art gallery in the village. Dinner will be traditional cooked on fire wood and earthen ware at the home stay. DAY 4: Departure from Sawantwadi Today you can sleep in and wake up to have a relaxed breakfast with your host family. After you finish your meal it will be time to pack up your belongings, say your goodbyes to your gracious host family and depart for your onward journey home, surely with many wonderful memories from your trip.
strTitle: Stay with Villagers, Hike Nature Trails and Enjoy Puppetry

strIntroduction: The smells, the sounds and the sights. Awaken your senses completely. If you are a nature lover, this package is for you. Spend your days exploring the flora and fauna of the jungles. Sindhudurg region is one of the 11 natural bio diversity reserves in the world. You will find variety of species of flora and fauna. Indeed a treat for the nature lover! Detailed Tour Itinerary DAY 1: Arrival in Sawantwadi Upon arrival at your home­stay in Sawantwadi, you will be warmly welcomed by your Indian host family with a traditional garland and tikka. Your hosts will then assist you with the registration procedure and show you to your room. Upon settling in you will be taken around the home­stay property and given the opportunity to meet and mingle with your host family. After getting to know one another you will have a delicious lunch together. After lunch you can choose to depart for an optional ‘experience’ of your choice or spend the day relaxing at your home­stay and enjoying the beautiful surroundings. In the evening you will enjoy another home cooked dinner and of course a truly relaxing nights’ sleep. DAY 2: Nature Trail Wake up early morning. Wear your sturdy walking shoes for an exciting trail into the Amboli Jungles. The Amboli jungles nestles some rare species of amphibians and reptiles. There are also some 108 odd varieties of butterflies. Your guide will take you into an exciting journey. The trail is 3 hrs long. After the trail, you will be treated to a delicious, hot breakfast. Back to the home stay. The afternoon is free for you to relax and soak in the peaceful atmosphere. In the evening you can sit down for another home cooked Indian dinner before heading off to bed. DAY 3: Snorkeling Today you can sleep in and have a relaxed breakfast as the morning is free at leisure for you to enjoy. You may want to join a cultural workshop or choose an optional ‘experience’ to keep yourself occupied. After lunch, you will be heading out for today’s exciting activity...Snorkeling! Enjoy the afternoon with a professional team assisting you as you discover the underwater world of this spectacular region. In the evening, head back to your home­stay for a delicious dinner prepared by your host family and another peaceful nights’ sleep. DAY 4: Bear Trail Enjoy a tasty breakfast at your home­stay before heading out to the Dajipur Jungles for bear sighting. Enjoy the gorgeous flora and fauna of the region while driving through the jungle. With some luck and professional guidance you might just see a real bear! After the trail you will have lunch before enjoying the rest of the day at leisure. Perhaps you want to venture into town and go for an optional shopping trip to find treasures for yourself and loved ones at the local market. In the evening you will return to your home­stay for a specially prepared dinner and a good nights' sleep. DAY 5: Departure from Sawantwadi Today you can sleep in and wake up to have a relaxed breakfast with your host family. After you finish your meal it will be time to pack up your belongings, say your goodbyes to your gracious host family and depart for your onward journey home, surely with many wonderful memories from your trip.
strTitle: Explore the Indian Jungle and Stay with a Rural Family

strIntroduction: Marathas were a formidable force in the country in the 16­17 century. The Maratha empire had spread its wings from the Sahayadri range in the western Ghats to Attack, the north west frontier of the country. Spearheaded by the visionary King Shivaji, the Great, the Sindhudurg forts stands a testimonial. Detailed Tour Itinerary DAY 1: Arrival in Sawantwadi Upon arrival at your home­stay in Sawantwadi, you will be warmly welcomed by your Indian host family with a traditional garland and tikka. Your hosts will then assist you with the registration procedure and show you to your room. Upon settling in you will be taken around the home­stay property and given the opportunity to meet and mingle with your host family. After getting to know one another you will have a delicious lunch together. After lunch you can rest for a while. After your afternoon tea, you can visit the palace. Sawantwadi Palace is the seat of the royal family of Bhosale. The family traces its antecedents to Shivaji, the Great Maratha warrior. You will be meeting the Queen, Smt Satvashila raje Bhosale. You can go around the palace grounds, visit the in-­house museum and darbar hall. Later , you can take a walk in the market and head back to your homestay. DAY 2: Sindhudurg Fort Wake up and enjoy the warmth of a home made Indian breakfast prepared caringly by your host family. Today you will visit the Sindhudurg fort, the only fort to have been built in the middle of the sea. It’s a wonder. You will be taken down the history lane. Sindhudurg Fort stands as a testimonial to Shivaji, The great Maratha warrior’s vision and foresightedness. You will head back to the homestay for a late lunch. Evening at leisure. DAY 3: Vijaydurgh Fort and Girye Today you will have the opportunity to visit yet another Fort. Vijaydurgh was captured by Shivaji, the great Maratha warrior from the Siddhis. This fort is 850 years old. Its a beautiful fort by the sea and is a proud testimonial of valour. Lunch will be in a mango orchard on the way back to the homestay. You can have relaxed evening at your homestay. DAY 4: Departure from Sawantwadi Today you can sleep in and wake up to have a relaxed breakfast with your host family. After you finish your meal it will be time to pack up your belongings, say your goodbyes to your gracious host family and depart for your onward journey home, surely with many wonderful memories from your trip.
strTitle: Tryst With Royalty: Palaces and Forts of Sawantwadi

strIntroduction: You will take a walk through a local bazaar of Old Delhi, experiencing the variety of food and visiting one of the best well maintained last standing Havelis old-style 3-storied home (Old Private Mansion) with a central courtyard flanked by rooms with 58 doors. The Bazaars of Old Delhi Bazaars have colorful and interesting street food and host the oldest shops serving delicacies from around the world. The best of the best chaat (Indian snack) can be enjoyed here: Chat Papri, Laccha Tokri, Guliya, Desi Ghee Tikki, Moong Pakori, Kulche Chole, Dahi Bhalla, Bedwee Aloo and Kachori Alu are just lip smacking. Apart from that you can also have Samudra Kee Chat, Brown & White fresh milk cake, Kulfi, Ice creams, Hot Kadai Milk, Halwa Nangori etc. The area is also home to several small temples, shrines, old mosque and protected monument sight. Cows wander the streets, small dharamshalas (rest-houses) and pyaus (water-stations) attest to the pious contributions of local merchants. After the walk, we will take you to a Hindu home - Masterji Kee Haveli (Old Private Mansion) in Old Delhi, for a demonstration and tasting of traditional home-style Indian vegetarian cooking Class. Masterji Kee Haveli is a fine edifice that has been built on the lines of traditional Mughal architecture. Any onlooker is sure to be impressed with the carved stone pillars where a complimentary delicious traditional meal will be served in bronze utensils. You can choose to participate in the Cooking Class, or merely watch and learn. Please note that this is not a Cooking Class lesson; it is a chance to visit a home and get a glimpse of daily life. The haveli has a beautiful terrace from where, during a clear day, you will enjoy a spectacular 360 degree view of Old Delhi and its higgledy-piggledy chaos which includes view of Jama Masjid, Chawri Bazar Metro Station, New Delhi Railway Station, Airport Metro Station, Jeevan Bharti Building - Connaught Place, Parikrama revolving restaurant, Gopal Das Building, MCD Civic Centre (The tallest building in Delhi) etc. The family is Hindu and vegetarian, and old time residents of Shahjahanabad. This is one of the few homes that hasn't been broken down or divided into pieces and sold to multiple people. It is a chance to visit a traditional home and see what life is really like in this narrow crowded part of Old Delhi, where adjacent houses share a common wall and everyone knows everyone else! Our passion is simple: to share with our guests the flavours of an Incredible India we treasure and love...
strTitle: Visit Old Delhi, from the Bazaar to the Traditional Home

strIntroduction: Calcutta is truly a melting pot of cultures and communities… truly a kaleidoscope of various shades, flavors and sights that made Calcutta what it is today! This tour will help you to understand a little bit of India and how so many religions and faith form the very fabric which is India. Find out amongst others about the Chinese who made Calcutta their home and gave Calcutta its amazing Chinese food. Find out the oldest surviving Christian tomb in the city, walk into synagogues which have stood for centuries within whose walls time still stands still. Taste local food and witness life as it unfolds right in front of you. Discover amazing facts about the Parsis and find hidden gems in the middle of nowhere. So many cultures and so many communities co-existing side by side, reminds one of the famous 1982 number one by Paul McCartney and Stevie Wonder – Ebony and Ivory. Come and see the various communities that made Calcutta their home on this tour!
strTitle: Culture Kaleidoscope - The Calcutta Culture Tour

strIntroduction: Discover the holy river and the magic of Old Delhi, with a visit to the mystic riverbank and a view of the ghats from the river. Behind every historical capital there is a great big river. The route is an ode to this river that has been a silent witness to Delhi’s history and is now a recurrent victim of its excesses. Starting from the little lanes of Shahjahanabad, while the city is still sleepy in its proverbial sockspassing along the magnificently formidable walls of the Red Fort we find ourselves on the meditative quiet banks of the Yamuna at Nigambodh Ghat. A boat-tride along its shores – migratory birds circling above the calm waters - unravels the ritualistic devotion with which the Hindus treat the historic river. Despite its current struggles with pollution, the Yamuna is a goddess to the eyes of her devotees. Concluding with a memorable view of the Jama Masjid back through the streets of Old Delhi, the Yamuna Route is a true experience in the stimulating contradictions that is India. During the summer season (Feb.-August), the Yamuna tour does not include the boat ride due to the water condition. The Yamuna tour will still include a fascinating stop at the riverbank and a visit to the nearby cow shelter.
strTitle: Bike along Delhi's Holy River: the Yamuna

strIntroduction: From the technicolor song and dance extravaganzas of the 1970s and 1980s to the blockbusters of today, Bollywood is a tradition as essential to India - and more specifically Mumbai - as Hollywood is to America and LA. Exceeding its American rival for sheer chutzpah and volume, Bollywood belongs to Mumbai and this full-day tour belongs to you. You will be picked up from your Mumbai hotel and taken to a location site to see a movie being shot. First, you'll be escorted to a specially created studio and receive an intimate look behind the scenes to see technicians at work on a live shooting set. Not only will you get to watch a film being shot, but you'll even get a sneak peek at everything that goes on behind-the-scenes during the shoot. Depending on the schedule, you may even get a chance to visit the actors or actresses makeup rooms and pose for souvenir snapshots with some of today's Bollywood stars! After this, we'll take you to a Bollywood Museum. While being escorted to an air-conditioned Dance Hall with a decorated stage and music system in Bollywood style, you'll get a glimpse of famous Bollywood actors' posters and photographs lining the walls. Here though, the highlight is the chance to watch 3-4 Bollywood dance shows performed by professional dancers live. Depending on the day's schedule, after lunch at a local restaurant, you'll either get to visit a VFX studio or travel to visit an old heritage cinema where you'll experience how Bollywood movies look on a big screen. If you go to the VFX studio, you'll get to see how they create sets, choreograph dance scenes, and rehearse stunts. If we go to the heritage cinema, you'll get to look at the projection room where things have hardly changed since the golden age of Hindi cinema and watch the latest Bollywood movie at a cinema. Before being dropped off at your hotel or any other location in Mumbai, the day ends with a tour past the homes of famous Bollywood stars in exclusive areas of Mumbai.
strTitle: A Behind The Scenes Look at Bollywood

strIntroduction: If you have been amazed at the amazingly beautiful idols you see during the Bengali festivals like Durga Puja and Kali Puja and always wanted to get behind the scenes then you will love this tour. This tour takes you to the traditional potters’ quarter in the north of the city where these potters were forced to move when the British East India Company decided to build the new settlement and separate districts were allotted to the Company’s workmen. With the Pujas becoming grander every year these potters have moved from dubious existence to a sought after profession. Not only does this neighborhood supply gods and goddess to the city but many of their creations are exported. It has been termed as one of the seven wonders of Calcutta and thus being in the city you surely cannot give it a miss. Book this tour to discover nuances of this amazing art and document it with amazing photographs!
strTitle: The Goddess Beckons - Artisans' Colony Photo Tour

strIntroduction: If you really want to get into the thick of things and see and photograph markets like you have never seen before, sign up for this one. If people and photographing people in their natural environment and crowded market-places is what gets you going then you need to sign up for this one. And if we mentioned crowded market-places we really mean crowded. But we promise you the effort will be worth it. Some amazing activity just waiting to be captured by you! One of the biggest wholesale vegetable market of Calcutta, it offers your sights, smells and experiences you would have never ever imagined or experienced before. The opportunities and challenges this tour offers to photographers are unparalleled. Come, shoot and experience a sea of humanity!
strTitle: Mesmerizing Markets Photo Tour

strIntroduction: Dalhousie Square, now known as B. B. D. Bagh was what was once the central business district. It was the nerve centre of Job Charnock’s Calcutta.Rudyard Kipling in his “A Tale of Two Cities” writes : “Thus the midday halt of Charnock -- more's the pity! Grew a City. As the fungus sprouts chaotic from its bed, So it spread -- Chance-directed, chance-erected, laid and built On the silt -- Palace, byre, hovel -- poverty and pride -- Side by side;” This tour – which serves as a wonderful introduction to the city - takes you through the hows and whys of Calcutta helping you retrace the steps that gave birth to this second city of the Empire. Liberal doses of history with lots of photographic opportunities makes this heritage site a must do if you visit Calcutta. Calcutta which was once tipped as not only the handsomest town in Asia but one of the finest in the world is an enigma waiting to be discovered. Come and see the past come alive on this tour with us.
strTitle: European Calcutta - Discover Calcutta

strIntroduction: In this activity, we'll explore Meghalaya. Meghalaya is a land of indigenous tribes with diverse cultures, beliefs and costumes, consisting of the Khasi, the Jaintia, and the Garo Hills. The Khasi and Jaintia Hills form the central and eastern part of Meghalaya and are higher in elevation than the Garo Hills. These hills are full of limestone deposits. These slopes also get more rainfall annually than anywhere else in the world. All these factors come together to make for ideal conditions for cave formation. In this exploratory trip, we'll learn the basics of caving – or spelunking – and begin to explore the state's limestone caves. We'll also hike the historic David Scott trail, snorkel and dive in one of the clearest rivers in the world, as well as visit the double decker root bridge, the only one of it's kind in the world. Come join us as we explore this diverse and magical land. We will be joined by a team of expert cavers from the region who have spent their lives exploring the area. A team of guides, with mountaineering and first aid certifications, will also accompany you. ITINERARY : 11th March 2013: Shillong to Cherrapunjee – Hike the David Scott Trail Overnight in dormitory in Sa-I-Mika, Cherrapunjee Meals: None 12th March 2013: Caving to Krem Mawmluh Overnight in dormitory in Sa-I-Mika, Cherrapunjee Meals: None 13th March 2013: Trek to Living Root Bridges Overnight in dormitory in Sa-I-Mika, Cherrapunjee Meals: None 14th March 2013: Introduction to Vertical Caving- Krem Ri-Blai Overnight in dormitory in Sa-I-Mika, Cherrapunjee Meals: None 15th March 2013: Cherrapunjee – Mawlynnong Village - Shnongpdeng Village campsite Meals: Breakfast, lunch, and dinner 16th March 2013: Rapelling & Ziplining in Shnongpdeng Meals: Breakfast, Lunch 17th March 2013: Depart Before you say goodbye to the Geckos today, don’t forget to buy some orange flower honey. You can also buy cinnamon and other spices that are cultivated in and near Cherrapunji. You should definitely buy Meghalaya tea which has a distinctly lighter flavor compared with Assam or Darjeeling tea.
strTitle: 3/11-17 Exploratory Caving Trip in Meghalaya

strIntroduction: Enjoy the lush green hills of Meghalaya by camping out in mesmerizing Mawphlang. Visit traditional Khasi villages, interact with the locals and try unique ethnic dishes. Mawphlang is a perfect weekend getaway for a relaxing outdoor & cultural experience. Itinerary: Day 1: Leave Guwahati early morning for Lynkien village via Shillong. Set up camp at Maplepine farm by the river. Explore nearby areas and visit the local Khasi village. Interact with locals. Campfire in the evening. (optional - try ethnic Khasi dishes) Dinner at 9 PM Day 2: After breakfast, go out for a short hike to the Mawphlang sacred forest. Picnic lunch at the forest. get back to camp by afternoon. Leisure time. Campfire in the evening. Dinner at 9 PM Day 3: After breakfast drive out to Shillong and then to Lake Umiam. Halt for a while at the lake and drive back to Guwahati to reach by afternoon. Trip ends.
strTitle: Camp and Hike the Lush Green Hills of Megalaya

strIntroduction: We've all had those moments of looking out at a distant snow-capped mountain from our airplane window or seeing a poster of unreal white slopes or watching videos of people racing down mountains on their snowboard. Here's your chance to bring that distant image closer. Along with Memcorp, we're taking you on a dream journey to Gulmarg! With training from certified professionals, we'll make our way down the majestic slopes, swishing and swirling in the snow! Explore the beautiful Kashmiri sights while snowboarding through the day and discover star patterns in the night-sky, bundled up by a bonfire! Make friends, share stories and take back memories for a lifetime! Come strike snowboarding off your bucket list! Get Snow Stoked!
strTitle: Snowboard in the Himalayas & Enjoy Kashmir's Gorgeous Sights

strIntroduction: Jaipur is famous for its printed textiles, the traditional Jaipur print is synonymous with big and small bootis, or jaals and borders with repeated patterned floral designs seen in today's Bagru and Sanganer prints. Our first look into Jaipuri textiles will be Bagru, known for natural dyes and hand block printing. We will visit the iconic workshop of a master craftsman and award winning Bagru and Indigo artist. This will be the starting point of our intellectual expedition into the craft of Bagru printing, seen on Rajasthani skirts (ghagras) and scarves for women (odhnis). You will discover the deep connections between the past and the present of Indian textile. With a textile designer at the helm, we will explore how block printing and traditional textile design can interact with contemporary fashion accessories. We will meet a traditional block maker and printer that will give us a peek into his collection of exquisite brass blocks, hand blocks which are no longer available and are priceless. As we look in awe at the intricate sharpness of every carving, we will feel the painstaking time and effort involved in each stage of the production process. Visiting local production workshops and discussing with designers and textile producers will allow you to develop a unique understanding of the textile universe, one filled with color and rooted in tradition and old-world techniques. We will end up with our hands colored with blues, pinks and reds after testing our skills at hand block printing with pigments! You will get an interactive, hands-on experience unlike any other. Leading textile craftsmen will offer you a fresh new perspective on the technical composition of Indian textiles as we pace ourselves through exquisite handmade garments adorned with silver and gold warq printing. A trip to Jaipur is incomplete without visiting the famous Anokhi Museum of Hand Printing. Textiles have been a fundamental presence in Jaipur, and though it may just be art to some and tools to others, the Anokhi Museum reminds us that textiles are not only a livelihood but continue to be an evolving culture breathing through the stages of contemporary revival. We will close the trip with a walk around the old bazaars and some gastronomical explorations of the regional cuisines of Rajasthan.
strTitle: Patterns in the Desert - Textile Trail in Jaipur

strIntroduction: You might know what goes into your favourite coffee bottle. But to know just what is behind it, go a little beyond the label. And come with us to Chikmagalur. Trust us, you'll never look at your morning brew the same again. Saying "coffee" seems incomplete without saying "estate" right after. So let's start there. Bound by the Bhadra River on one side and rolling hills on the other three, this nearly 100-year-old estate sprawls over 350 lush acres. It's still run by the family that founded it and, needless to say, their love of the land shows all over the estate.
