Take, for instance, the care and love with which the original planter's bungalow has been maintained. That's where you'll be staying, by the way. Set amidst of fruit trees, this 50 year old marvel boasts exquisite planters' furniture casually strewn around its drawing room, dining room and four bedrooms. It comes with the whole complement of efficient staff, the crown jewel of which is the most aptly named Amma, the resident cook who puts out spreads as if guests were her own children. We've also organised cookinges in which Amma will gladly show you how she weaves her magic. But if you think this breakaway is about sitting back and lazily sleeping off Amma's gastronomic indulgences, think again. With its towering old trees shrouded in broad leaves and creepers and the roads little more than dirt tracks, the property is more Entwood than estate. And it throws up an almost Tolekinesque range of experiences for the intrepid. There's a drive up to the highest peak, from where we can enjoy a peg or a mug and admire the setting sun as it winks goodbye over the Bhadra River. There's an easy trek through the woods, picking herbs and leaves, including those favoured by bison (while they aren't looking, of course) and bringing them back to the house for Amma to transform into delicious chutneys. There's also a short walk to a secret waterhole, where you can try your luck at some joy fishing and on a short stroll to the nearby bridge, where watching thousands of fruit bats (not of the Dracula variety) take off against the evening sky is a sight you're not likely to forget any time soon. And then, our piece de resistance - a night walk around the estate, where we might run into some deer, wild boar and if we're really lucky, bison. You can't come to a coffee estate without meeting the star of the show, can you? And since its picking season, the star is out on show. We'll take you picking and teach you not just which beans to pick, but also how to roast them. And that's not all. Did you know that coffee estates play the perfect hosts for pepper farming? No? Then you also wouldn't know that pepper is another thing you're going to learn to pick. We'd also love to promise you areca nut picking, but clambering up a dangerously thin looking palm and jumping from one to the other might not be your cup of coffee. Don't worry though - the beans you've picked most certainly will be. So come, breakaway and discover just why there's more to your coffee than the beans or their blend.
strTitle: What's Behind your Brew? A Coffee Plantation Trail in India

strIntroduction: Over the years one place has come to represent the essence of Mumbai: 'commerce', 'the sea', and the harmonious balance between the two, like no other. One has to meet the Kolis, the original, seafaring inhabitants of this city, to know how perfectly that balance can be struck. A leisurely cup of tea with a crisp newspaper is not the kind of morning known to the folks at Sassoon docks - the hub of a large chunk of fish trading in Mumbai. The mornings at the docks are pretty hectic - at the crack of dawn, boats and trawlers harbour their way in with a bountiful of fresh catch. The frenzied activity that ensues continues till mid-day, the pace of which can put any stock exchange to shame. Chefs, housewives, exporters, small time traders all vie for the best catch. After a session of frenetic trading, either the brave or the truly fortunate are rewarded with the treasure. Interestingly, this fish trade is controlled by the women, as the men folk are busy with fishing. If you are brave enough to elbow your way through the market, keep up with the frenzied activity and don't mind the smell of fish, then this is one side of Mumbai you won't want to miss. Away from the crazy hum-drum of the fish market, hop into a signature black & yellow cab to visit Koliwada, the Machimaar colony of Cuffe Parade, which is just a stone's throw away from the docks. Lines of small houses with TV antennas and an assortment of beached boats typify the juxtaposition of old and new in this settlement. This is home to the fishing community - better known as 'Kolis' this colourful community wears its heart on its sleeve. As you enter the village, you see koli women working with their men folk helping to dry, clean and get the fish ready to sell. They've all had a very early start to the morning, from what we've seen at Sassoon docks. The fishing culture is reflected in their folk dances and songs which celebrate sea faring traditions of the community. In unison, they worship the sea. They live in tight clusters and are known for their unique culture & customs. A walk in this colony is a metaphorical journey through the alleys of their very heritage & traditions. Breakaway to Sassoon Docks with us and the next time you smell fish you will surely think of the Kolis.
strTitle: The Sea and We: Koli Culture in Bombay

strIntroduction: Criss-crossing narrow lanes, tiny shops spilling with colourful wares, people haggling for a better deal... Welcome to the bazaars of India! You can find them everywhere, even juxtaposed against high rises and glitzy malls, these bazaars fiercely hold their own. The bursting metropolis of Mumbai has many such gems hidden in its folds. Care to taste the spicy tears-in-the-eyes signature of the Maharashtrian masala? Head straight to the Lalbagh spice market. Guntur, Bedki, Reshampatti or Kashmiri; no we are not planning a travel itinerary. These are the names of the variety of chillies one would find in the lalbaug spice market. An expert eye could tell one from the other. Each has a specific purpose... some provide the fiery red colour without the heat, and some could be scalding hot. This market is also home to spice mixes so authentic, which the pickiest grandma would approve. You just need to let your nose lead you - the aromas will guide you to the spices long before you see them. Here, you can not only buy the spices, but can also get them dry roasted and ground into the masala mix of your choice... before your own eyes. It's not uncommon to see ladies patiently waiting, with bagful of spices, for their turn. After you have had your fill of the spices, we move on to Null bazaar. Roam the bazaar to find utensils, crockery, odds and ends for the house, the list goes on & on. Looking for a desi barbecue set? Find it at Null Bazaar! Just across the street from Null bazaar is Chor Bazaar. Once a well kept secret and reserved only for the adventurous, the notorious Chor Bazaar or Thieves Market welcomes connoisseurs and beginners with equal warmth. Furniture from the Raj, rare electronics like vintage gramaphones, out-of-print LPs, film posters that take your back to your parents' time, coins and stamps from a time when they had currency... it's not uncommon to find a genuine antique here. And if these guys can't find something for you, it probably doesn't exist. Gems from here often find their way into curated collections of lifestyle stores . The labyrinth of narrow lanes beckons the enthusiastic traveler. One can easily spend a day in this Aladdin's Cave. The more adventurous can try their hand at bargaining. Be warned - do not begin if you don't intend to buy. So let's go bazaar hopping. We have enough to have you sold on it, whether you buy anything or not.
strTitle: Sold before Buying: Explore the Bazaar Trails of Mumbai

strIntroduction: Hand Painted Type tour is about experiencing typography in the old part of the city and getting to meet the typical Indian sign painters and get some insight into their world. With the world adopting to flex and digitally printed banners, hand painted signs have disappeared. This tour is about getting to know a landscape which has not changed for over 100 years mixed with typical chaos of modern Delhi. Its about going in lanes of Old Delhi on cycle rickshaws and getting to meet painters; you'll even be able to get some customized signs if you like.
strTitle: Meet India's Talented Street and Hand Painters

strIntroduction: Live one day of your life as something other than just a biker. Live one day of your life as one of our villagers. Travel and ride 220kms from Mumbai with us and come breathe – fresh air, eat – simple yet delicious local cusines, partake – in village activites working alongside farmers in a field and ride around our village to learn about local myths and interesting stories.
strTitle: Escape from Mumbai by Motorbike

strIntroduction: This is one of the first villages adopted by Grassroutes, where the local self-development initiative was encouraged. Like most villages across India, this one too has its legends, its very own people and several unique offerings for those who come from the other urban world. At 1000 m above sea level in the western ghats, between river Kurkundi and river Mula, the local folklore connects the village to the legend of goddess zakobhai, to whom one of Purushwadi’s temples is dedicated. It is believed that the goddess lifted up five Hanuman statues from different villages in the region and threw them in the nearby Mula river, a feat she repeats every year when the statues are put upright. The local communities are predominantly tribal and concentrate on cultivation and animal husbandry for their livelihoods. Among the different tribes of the region are bails, kolis mahadeos, thakars, koli dhors, takare kolis, paradhis, kokanas, warlis, kathodis and katkaris. Here's a sample of the experiences you'll enjoy: - Stay with a local in Rural India. - Eat Organic Vegetarian food prepared by the Local Women. - Trekking - Nature Walks - Temple Tour - Riverside Fun & Games - Pluck your fruits - Rice Pounding/Collecting Water/Pluck and eat! - Learn how to grow your own food - Chopping wood for the Bonfire [If it’s not raining!]] - Preparing food with the Women - Corn Barbecue / Toasting Marshmallows around the bonfire
strTitle: Experience Village Life in Purushwadi

strIntroduction: Yoga, a term coined for physical, mental and spiritual discipline has its roots coming from ancient India. Yoga is a way of life, unlike only understanding it as physical forms or breathing exercises. At Freedom, our yoga studio, every asana is hence linked with a yogic atitude, better known as Bhava, to get a complete Body, Mind and Soul experience. In this experience, we will get you to touch base with your inner self with meditation techniques, feeling confident and stronger through yogic asanas (postures), feeling alert, relaxed and rejuvenated with pranayams. Also, we'll help you choose a healthy diet plan that goes best with your work, routine, exercise and lifestyle. Our beautiful open air studio is in a natural serene setting: the sea which is just an arm length away will make you want to come back over and over again! To summarise, this experience at Freedom will make you realise that progress towards a healthier lifestyle is a MUST. You can choose between one of the following 60 mins session 1. Yoga 2. Yoga, Meditation and Pranayam 3. Meditation and Pranayam 4. Functional Training 5. Pilates 6. A detailed De-tox AHAR (Diet) plan A detailed De-tox AHAR (Diet) plan session can be chosen in addition with any of the first five options.
strTitle: Yoga overlooking a beautiful view of the Sea

strIntroduction: Spend a day in love with water in the city! Lakes spread all over Delhi, a saga of water in the city. Some brimming with abundance, and some dried up in today’s waterless climate. Some natural lakes, and some man made ones. Visit holy lakes, historical lakes, Brimming with stories if not water, And spend a day learning to love water... Places we'll visit: - Surajkund Lake, just outside Delhi, 10th century - Haus Khas Reservoir, 13th century - Sarovar at Bangla Sahib, 17th century - Naini Lake, Model Town, 20th century Photos by: Jyoti Prakash Bhattacharjee, Varun Shiv Kapur, Karan Thapa, Mayank Austen Soofi, Carole Harris, Kabilan Sathyamurthy, Ken Wieland, Vasudha Wadhera
strTitle: Lakes of Delhi: Spend a Day Learning to Love Water

strIntroduction: Learn about Sikhism by visiting prominent Sikh temples of Delhi This walk takes you to some of the main historic Gurudwaras (sikh shrines) of Delhi. In the process we will learn more about Sikhism, its teachings and tenets and the inspiring lives of some of its Gurus. We will listen to shabad kirtan (Sikh devotional hymns), enjoy karah prasad (a sweet preparation) and langar, a community offering of food. Places we'll visit: - Sis Ganj Gurudwara, the shrine of Guru Tegh Bahadur, the 9th Sikh guru, set in idyllic Chandni Chowk, Old Delhi - Gurudwara Bangla Sahib, the shrine of Guru Har Krishan, the 8th guru of the Sikhs, near Connaught Place - Gurudwara Rakab Ganj Sahib Photos by: Kabilan Sathyamurthy, Karan Thapa, Bharat Bijlani, Mayank Austen Soofi
strTitle: Visit the Sikh Temples of New Delhi

strIntroduction: Explore, Eat, Enjoy! Explore the geography of food in the city with this food walk that takes you to the treats that the Pahad Ganj area has in store for you. Sample special traditional Indian foods, classic recipes that have stood the test of time, and enjoy also the cosmopolitan pleasure of devouring food from all over the world in New Delhi’s hippie tourist district. As we go about eating, we will also discover, shop, explore, faff around. Some places we'll visit (Options): - Jalebiwala, Main Bazaar - German Bakery, Main Bazaar - Choor-choor Naan, Multani Dhanda - Sitaram Dewan Chand (Chole Bhature) - Kachoriwala, Panchkuian Road - Kaleva (Sweet shop) in Gol Market - Panchayat (Pan shop) in Connaught Place
strTitle: Explore, Eat and Enjoy in New Delhi: Pahad Ganj

strIntroduction: Exploring night-life in Shahjahanabad The city of Shahjahanabad (17th century) is often regarded as the largest and busiest medieval cities of India. A happy mix of commerce, heritage and layers of history and built heritage from across the centuries – Mughal, British and contemporary; mind blowing street food; the lovely people of the walled city, and their infectious joie de vivre – all weave a fascinating web for the walker. This excursion however has no other agenda but to explore the life of the city at night. The treasure-house of experiences continues to delight our senses at all times of the day – and at night the magic of Old Delhi is a different one, almost a parallel life. We will start our walk at Sisganj Gurudwara, followed by a visit to the next door Sunahri Masjid, and a quick sweet stop at Kanwarji’s, followed by dinner at Gali Paranthe Wali. We then proceed to explore the hidden wonders that the city offers in its million by-lanes. Walking though Ballimaran’s plentiful bakeries and chai shops, we will wander towards Jama Masjid, and revel in the glittering bazaars around the mosque that shine on till the wee hours of the morning. From here, we end up at Darya Ganj and finally conclude the walk at Delhi Gate, going through Darya Ganj’s eclectic mix of art deco colonial buildings. Photos by: Author EmG, Carole Harris, Mckay Savage, Mayank Austen Soofi
strTitle: Night Walk in Chandni Chowk

strIntroduction: Relishing exotic delicacies in the old city. The food of Delhi is a gastronome’s and connoisseurs dream come true. We will wander in the lanes of Old Delhi, in search of forgotten foods, scintillating flavors from centuries ago, that are still alive in the melting pot of Delhi’s culture. Some places we'll visit (options): - Khari Baoli: Asia’s largest spice market, shop here for food supplies and sharbats (summer coolers) - Chawri Bazaar: Ashok Chaat Bhandar,(Indian street food); Bade Miyaan’s Kheer (dessert) - Gali Paranthe Wali (Indian stuffed bread) - Amritsari Lassi Wala (yoghurt drink) - Jalebiwala, Dariba Kalan (sweet shop) - Sitaram Bazaar for Kulfis (Indian ice desserts) Photos by: Carole Harris, Michael Vito, Bharat Bijlani, Kabilan Sathyamurthy, Carole Harris, Bedatri Datta Choudhury, Parul Thapa, VasudhaWadhera
strTitle: Food Walk in Old Delhi: Chaat, Lassi, Jalebi, Kulfi and more

strIntroduction: Stories of sufis, emperors & poets in one of Delhi’s oldest village. The village named after Hazrat Nizamuddin Auliya (1236-1325), one of the most popular Sufi saints of North India, is a treasure house of stories and histories. At the epicenter is the Dargah of Nizamuddin, set in the bustling village with a medieval ambience, narrow alleys, and bazaars. Because of its association with the saint, the area became a popular site for burials – for emperors, saints, nobility, royalty, warriors and poets alike. Nizamuddin offers a bouquet of built heritage down the centuries, besides of course the chance to meet with the beloved Nizam Piya. Places we'll visit: - The Dargah complex and nearby monuments: Tomb of Ghalib, Chaunsath Khamba & more - Chilla Nizamuddin - Humayun’s Tomb, mausoleum of the 2nd mughal, a world heritage site, 16th century - Tomb of the poet Rahim Khan-e-Khanan, 17th c. - Sunder Nursery, India’s largest nursery Photos by: Karan Thapa, Bedatri Datta Choudhury, Chandan Ahuja, Varun Shiv Kapur, Karan Thapa, Varun Shiv Kapur, Kabilan Sathyamurthy, Deepanjali, Soham Banerjee
strTitle: Follow the Footsteps of Saints, Emperors and Poets

strIntroduction: Rediscover the historic baolis (stepwells) of the cities of Delhi! In a world where water is constantly depleting, In Search of Lost Water takes you to water bodies of medieval Delhi to highlight traditional wisdom in water conservation and management. See baolis spread over the modern city of Delhi, built across the centuries by different dynasties, belonging to the different historic cities of Delhi. We will discover lost community spaces, hear the laughter still echoing in the step-wells, eavesdrop on gossip, in search of lost water... Places we'll visit: Agrasen ki Baoli, Hailey Road Hazrat Nizamuddin ki Baoli (14century) Gandak ki Baoli, Mehrauli (13century) Rajon ki Baoli, Mehrauli (16century)
strTitle: In Search of Lost Water: Baolis (step-wells) of Delhi

strIntroduction: Hone your green thumb, become a gardener, enjoys history & greenery. We take you to the popular nurseries of Delhi, both government and private owned. The nurseries of Delhi are not just places where you can buy plants, seeds and gardening equipment, but experiences that come alive with the history and culture that surrounds them. Places we'll visit: - Sunder Nursery, Nizamuddin: India’s largest nursery spread over 70 acres, dotted with historical monuments - Mehrauli Flower Market: a popular flower market selling fresh flowers every morning - Chiragh Nursery, Chiragh Dilli - Rajdhani Nursery, Jorbagh Photos by: Karan Thapa and Mayank Austen Soofi
strTitle: Explore the Plant Nurseries of Delhi

strIntroduction: Explore the old and new cities of Delhi by the lakeside. The Hauz Khas Village complex is a lovely example of many historic cities breathe together to make Delhi one of the most fascinating historic cities of the world. Historic monuments from the 13th and 14th centuries, reign tall over the Hauz Khas – the royal tank; and 21st century markets, art and design enterprises, bookshops and hubs of activity and recreation spring up in the vicinity. Come explore this meeting of times in the heart of Delhi. Places we'll visit: - Hauz Khas Monuments and Reservoir - Kunzum, a travel café - Art galleries, design stores & bookshops etc.. - Jagannath Temple Photos by: Kunzum, Shweta Modgil, Shweta Modgil, Carole Harris, Mayank Auten Soofi, Carole Harris
strTitle: Explore Hauz Khas: the cultural and creative center of Delhi

strIntroduction: A meditative pilgrimage to Buddhist centres of Delhi. Learn about teachings of the Buddha, and offer your prayers at some important centres of Buddhism in Delhi. Places we'll visit: - Buddha Jayanti Park, set in the lush and verdant environs of the Delhi ridge, houses a statue of Buddha and a Bodhi tree. - Ladakh Buddhist Vihar, by the banks of the Yamuna, houses a beautiful Buddhist temple, as well as a bustling clothes market. - Tibetan Colony at Majnu ka Tila - a recreation of another world, another place in the city of Delhi. Narrow criss-crossing streets, shops selling Tibetan crafts, jewellery, books, eateries serving authentic Tibetan food, and a small monastery. Photos by: Hideyuki Kamon, Wikimedia Common, Olzhas Giovanni Bozay, Bedatri Datta Choudhury, Mayank Austen Soofi
strTitle: Learn about Delhi's Buddhist Roots and Pray in Temples

strIntroduction: Explore village life at the periphery of the city On the periphery of Delhi unique and amazing structures are coming up. Bitooras, literally store houses made from cow-dung cakes have stopped passers-by in their tracks. These extraordinary constructions, made by local village women, are reminiscent of tiny houses, and are inscribed with wonderful abstract patterns and sometimes studded with mosaics. Our village walk takes us to see some of the best examples. Watch a demonstration of the fascinating process of the bitooras being made and participate! This walk is a vivid reminder of a fast-disappearing rural life that surrounds the city. We will be transported into the village by ox-cart, view the bitooras, chat to local farmers in their farmyards and sample delicious fresh lassi. This walk was originally conceived by UK based artist Andrew Burton. Photos by Andrew Burton
strTitle: Discover the Endangered Rural Architecture Outside Delhi

strIntroduction: Where have all the flowers gone? Posthumously yours, the flower markets of Delhi: The 3 main flower markets at Fatehpuri, Connaught Place and Mehrauli, an integral part of the city’s heritage and culture, and temples of beauty amidst the concrete jungle are now history, thanks to the Delhi government’s myopia. Come witness a disaster of urban planning and the lack of common sense in this city, as we visit the sites of the markets and experience the sad and eerie silence where once a million flowers bloomed. We will trace how the flower trade has reconfigured itself around these sites, and also visit Ghazipur, a landfill outside the city where part of the flower trade has been officially relocated. Itinerary & places we'll visit: - Homage to Mehrauli market, walking through the site - Exploring new informal markets around Mehrauli and Chattarpur - A visit to Ghazipur, the official new flower market Photos by: Saurabh Mehta, Monica Kapur, Meher & Karan, Saptorishi Majumndar, Shilpa Sharma, Harshvardhana Durugadda
strTitle: (The disappeared) Flower Markets of Delhi

strIntroduction: Andhra, like so much of India has had multiple influences in the area of arts and crafts, be it handloom weaving techniques or metal crafts, paintings or toy making. The crafts have been influenced by the material available locally or the skills learnt from traders or visitors to the area. Most of them flourished due to the encouragement received from the kings and noblemen of the time. This Detour would give us a glimpse of some of the main crafts of the region especially weaves like Ikkat, Himroo, Paithani and also metal crafts like Bidri and scroll paintings like Cherial.
strTitle: Discover the Crafts of Andhra: Handloom and Metalsmithing

strIntroduction: Walk in Mehrauli, the first of the seven cities that were built in Delhi and a location for building activity spanning across 10 centuries. Explore: - Akbar’s foster brother Adham Khan's Tomb built in 1562 - Gandhak ki Baoli- Step Well built early 13th CCE - An unnamed Mausoleum late 15th or early 16th CCE - Rajon Ki Baoli- Stepwell of “Masons” built in 1516 (so called because a group of masons had been living inside the mosque adjacent to the Baoli, till they were encouraged to find alternative accommodation in the early 1910s) - Metcalf's Bridge, built in mid 19th Century - Quli Khan's Mausoleum built in the 16th C, renamed Dilkusha and converted into a summer retreat by Thomas Theophilus Metcalfe, British resident at Delhi between 1813 -1853 Metcalf's Folly and Guest House also built on the same property The walk concludes at the Mausoleum of Ghyas-ud-Din Balban, the site of the earliest use of the true arch and Dome, but before this we visit the Mosque and Mausoleum of Sheikh Fazl-Ullah; this mosque's design was to have a lasting impact on Mosque designs to evolve in later centuries and the Stucco work on the ceiling in the mausoleum and the glazed tile work in combination with stucco work is breathtakingly beautiful. Through the walk you will be exposed to the gradual mixing of two traditions of construction and two separate traditions of architectural detailing and the eventual merging of the two into a complete whole that draws upon both the indigenous traditions and the central asian traditions and is yet singularly unique both in its detailing and its execution.
strTitle: Walk through Mehrauli's Ruins with a historian

strIntroduction: Design your own Indian traditional outfit – walk through shops to buy material of your choice, borders & other embellishments to go with it. Visit a local tailor who stitches it as per your design.
strTitle: Buy, Choose, Stitch and Wear your own Indian Outfit

strIntroduction: Welcome to a Delhi home. Come immerse yourselves into the mysteries of Indian Cooking. Unravel the secrets of the mouth watering dishes & discover the role of the numerous spices. Our culinary expert will give you hands on experience & teach you the nuances & secrets of making Indian food. Enjoy this experience in the house of a Dilli-walla (Delhiite) over great conversation, food & wine. The day ends with some singing of Bollywood music.
strTitle: Learn to Cook Indian Food and Unravel the Secrets of Spices

strIntroduction: Personalised shopping to bazaars of your choice. Walk through the maze of street shops or designer boutiques whatever your heart desires – from Indian handicrafts to furnishings, from eclectic souvenirs to fusion wear & accessories. Learn the art of bargaining the dilli-way. The experience ends at one of Delhi’s oldest clubs where you can relax with a drink & some snacks.
strTitle: Shop and Bargain in the Bazaars of Delhi

strIntroduction: An early morning drive to Agra from Delhi via the newly constructed Expressway. Explore the renowned Taj Mahal, and fall in love with it. Afterwards, visit quaint shops for local artifacts and grab a quick bite to give you some energy for the rest of the day. Discover the beautiful Agra Fort In the end, enjoy a short visit to a local village.
strTitle: Explore the Taj and Agra's Other Offbeat Treasures

strIntroduction: Visit the capital city of the Mughals - Shahjahanabad; it takes you back & forth in time. A walk through Jama Masjid & Red Fort & a rickshaw ride through the alleys of Chandni Chowk. Drive through the political powerhouses – Rashtrapati Bhawan, Parliament House & India Gate. Take a break & have a bite. Take a round of the temple complex that has prayer material, mehndi artists, colourful shops of bangles and other accessories. End the day with a visit to an ancient stepwell with interesting tales
strTitle: Tour Delhi Like a Local: Shahjahanabad

strIntroduction: For the multitasking superwoman between 30-­45 years old; a 2 day interlude; an opportunity to gently open the perfume bottle within her. To bond; to cry; to laugh; to frown; to gurgle and to jump... an opportunity just for 2 days to unmask and take in the glorious sunshine of her own being. Come Celebrate Women’s Day with us on 8th March 2013! Detailed Tour Itinerary DAY 1 We meet at 1045 p.m. at Dadar station (central). Our Representative from Culture Aangan will meet and greet you at the station. We embark together on an overnight train journey to Sindhudugrh. Sindhudugrh is called the California of India. It is the coastal district of our state of Maharashtra; vibrantly landscaped by God. DAY 2 We disembark at Sawantwadi station the next morning. Together we travel to our place of residence. We have chosen 2 homes for our stay. Nandan farms and Dwarka. On arrival welcome and registration process will be carried out. You can then transfer to your rooms, unpack.These 2 days are all about connecting to our inner child. Touch is the first step towards connection. We have on platter for you some most rejuvenating spa massages. Our masseurs with their expert fingers will gently ease out all the tension from your body and help you to relax completely. Lunch will be a scrumptious fare to pamper the foodie inside you. Post lunch Siesta is a must. An exciting evening awaits you. We start with a hot cup of ‘chai’. Let us then go and soil our hands in the potters clay and mould our feelings into figures; pretty souvenirs to carry back. A visit to the Sawantwadi Palace, meeting the Queen, walk in the market and shopping for cashew nuts and toys. Sawantwadi is popular also for its ‘gadbad’ icecream. A must. We come back to our homestay satiated . But wait.. the evening has just begun! A barbecue dinner and entertainment program in the mango orchard. This is the time to discover, as we have fun together. We have arranged some wonderful gifts for you. We introduce Dr. Meghana Dixit. She is an expert Ayurvedic doctor and a hypno therapist. She will conduct a series of small interesting meetings with each one of you. These will reflect aura scanning and interpretations, metaphor readings, hand writing analysis etc. These are preliminaries to our Sunday in depth interactions. This is the beginning to venture deeper in understanding of your own selves. DAY 3 Early morning rise and shine to the aromas of hot herbal tea. We move to the beach for an invigorating time to stretch and stretch and also to enjoy the expanse of the virgin beach and golden sands. Back to your rooms for breakfast and freshen up. The next 2 hrs will be fun filled with various mind enhancing activities. These 2 hours will witness the blooming of the ‘nav rasas’; a wonderful gift given to us at birth, but somewhere got trailed behind over the years as we got engrossed into our daily routine. Layer by layer we will slowly peal away the grease and grime that has settled over our inner self and voila! We stand, tall and shinning, a beautiful expression! Lunch will be another hearty meal followed by the much longed for afternoon nap. At tea time we shall have a small get together. We are interested to understand how these 2 days were for you. What was the most important thing that you discovered? This is the time for positive and constructive feedback from you. After which we depart to the railway station to catch our train back to Mumbai.
strTitle: Celebrate Woman's Day 2013 in a Retreat Outside of Mumbai

strIntroduction: While Rajasthan is one of India's most popular tourist destinations, known for its palaces and forts, there is another face to it: its people! With Culture Aangan, you can take the opportunity to connect with the people who contribute to the thickly woven, intrinsic social carpet. You will explore the villages of Rajasthan and experience firsthand, the various mechanisms that tick the village life. You can be a part of the morning opium meet, go spend the day with Rabaaddi Tribes, learn the art of Block Printing, and evenings watch the sun go down behind the awe inspiring rock formations. Detailed Tour Itinerary DAY 1: You alight at the Rani station if travelling by train or at the Jodhpur/ Udaipur airport. You will be met by our representative. Our representative will escort you to your place of stay. After welcome and registration, you can have refreshments and retire to your room for freshening and a rest. Later you can meet your hosts, get to know them. Lunch will be with the family. A Siesta. After afternoon tea, go for a farm walk. Evening spent in the farm with a firewood cooked dinner and a cultural show under the starlit skies. DAY 2: Early morning rise, after breakfast depart for Ranakpur, The Exquisite Carved Jain Temples. Today you will have a village lunch in a place called Bhanpura. Bhanpura is known for its Persian wheels still in use for irrigating the fields. After a lunch of Makke Ki Roti, Batuaye Ki Kadhi And Saag, you take your afternoon nap on the Charpayi under the mango tree. Have tea and leave for Kumbhalgarh fort, a magnificent fort nestling in the Aravalis, the oldest mountain range in the world and probably the most beautiful. Visit the fort and see the sound and light show. Return back to your stay in time for dinner. DAY 3: After a relaxed breakfast, spend the morning in horse farm. Learn all about the horses, how to breed them, groom them. Learn also basic riding. Lunch with the host family. After your tea make a visit to Ghanerao to see the beautiful step wells. Dinner will be back at the farms. An optional activity of going for a night trail is also available. DAY 4: After breakfast you bid goodbye to your hosts and proceed on your onward journey.
strTitle: Explore the Villages of Rajasthan and Learn Block Printing

strIntroduction: Rajasthan is well-known for its palaces and forts and one of the most famous destinations for tourists. However, Rajasthan has another face: its people! In this experience, not only will you get to stay like a royal at castle, but you'll also get to meet local Rajasthani people. You'll also get to explore villages and experience firsthand the various mechanisms that make the village tick. You can be a part of the morning opium meet, go spend the day with Rabaaddi Tribes, learn the art of Block Printing, and watch the sun go down behind the awe inspiring rock formations in the evenings. Detailed Itinerary DAY 1: You alight at the NANA station if travelling by train or at the Jodhpur/Udaipur airport. You will be met by our representative. Our representative will escort you to your place of stay. Welcome and registration, you can have refreshments and retire to your room for freshening and a rest. Later you can meet your hosts, get to know them. Lunch will be with the family. A siesta. After afternoon tea, you will be taken on a Tour of the Rawala, (a small haveli), your place of stay for the next 3 days. Later, you will visit the Rabbaddi Dhani, home of the shepherds. Participate in the blanket weaving activity from goat hair. Dinner will be with the Thakur Saab and his wife Ladissa. DAY 2: Early morning rise, after breakfast depart for Ranakpur, The Exquisite Carved Jain Temples. Today you will have a village lunch in a place called Bhanpura. Bhanpura is known for its Persian wheels still in use for irrigating the fields. After a lunch of Makke Ki Roti, Batuaye Ki Kadhi and Saag, you take your afternoon nap on the Charpayi under the mango tree. Have tea and leave for Kumbhalgarh Fort, a magnificent fort nestling in the Aravalis, the oldest mountain range in the world and probably the most beautiful. Visit the fort and see the sound and light show. Return back to your stay in time for dinner. DAY 3: After a relaxed breakfast, you can cycle to the Jawai Lake for crocodile sighting. Picnic at the lake. Come back to the Rawala for a siesta. Today, there will be a royal feast laid out for you. You can be a part of the preparations. Royal dinner with a cultural program. DAY 4: After breakfast, bid goodbye to your host family and proceed to your onward journey.
strTitle: Live like a King: Stay at a Palace & Visit Forts & Temples

strIntroduction: Rajasthan is a most popular tourist destination known for its palaces and forts. There is another face to Rajasthan: its people! With Culture Aangan, you can take the opportunity to connect with the people who contribute to the thickly woven, intrinsic social carpet. You will explore the villages of Rajasthan and experience firsthand the various mechanisms that tick the village life. You can be a part of the morning opium meet, go spend the day with Rabaaddi Tribes, learn the art of Block Printing, and evenings watch the sun go down behind the awe inspiring rock formations. Detailed Tour Itinerary DAY 1: You alight at the JAWAI Baandh station if travelling by train or at the Jodhpur/ Udaipur airport. You will be met by our representative. Our representative will escort you to your place of stay. Welcome and registration, you can have refreshments and retire to your room for freshening and a rest. Later you can meet your hosts, get to know them. Lunch will be the family. Galthani, a village in the Pali district, embodies even today, in the 21st century, all the elements that made a village in ancient times a self reliant unit. The village itself has grown in proportions and population today, but still retains the old architecture homes, the narrow lanes. You will be a part of the village community for the next 3 days. After tea, you will depart for leopard sighting. Late evening back to the village for dinner. DAY 2: Today the day is spent in the village.You will be taken on a conducted tour of the village. You will get to understand the story behind the functioning of the village. You will meet the important persons of the village, the movers and shakers – the potters, embroidery workers, the carpenters, school teachers and many more. Interact with them; learn the various traditional ways of cooking class. Evening, participate in a folk lore performance. DAY 3: Early morning rise, after breakfast depart for Ranakpur, the exquisite carved Jain Temples. Today you will have a village lunch in a place called Bhanpura. Bhanpura is known for its Persian wheels still in use for irrigating the fields. After a lunch of Makke Ki Roti, Batuaye Ki Kadhi And Saag, you take your afternoon nap on the charpayi under the mango tree. Have tea and leave for Kumbhalgarh Fort, a magnificent fort nestling in the Aravalis, the oldest mountain range in the world and probably the most beautiful. Visit the fort and see the Sound And Light Show. You return back to your stay in time for dinner. DAY 4: After breakfast, bid goodbye to your hosts and proceed for your onward journey
strTitle: Village Homestay in Rajasthan & visit its Forts and Temples

strIntroduction: Have you ever harbored a wish to own a piece of land and grow your own vegetables or food grains? This experience will give you the chance to be a farmer for a day! You will visit the local farmer in his field and learn the nuances of farming. You will also get the chance to sow the seeds, plough the field as per the need of the season, and have lunch with the farmer's family.
strTitle: Learn to Grow Vegetables & Have Lunch with a Farmer

strIntroduction: Places of Worship There are lots of pilgrimage destinations in Calcutta consisting of various temples, churches etc. There is a plethora of religious places in Calcutta, where you'll have an entirely different experience. These religious spots will energize you and take you into a new world that will completely relax your mind, body and soul. Kalighat Temple The name Calcutta is said to have been derived from the word Kalighat. Kalighat is regarded as one of the 51 Shakti Pheetas of India, where the various parts of Sati's body are said to have fallen, in the course of Shiva's Rudra Tandava. Infact, Calcutta Kalighat Kali temple has come in the top list of must see tourist attraction places. St Paul’s Cathedral Calcutta St. Paul's Cathedral is the first Episcopal Church of the Orient. The cathedral conforms to the Neo-Gothic or the Gothic Revival style of architecture that was greatly patronized by the British during the days of the colonial era. The architecture and the interim of the Saint Paul Cathedral is truly a feast for eyes. The atmosphere of this cathedral is very tranquil. St John’s Church St. John’s Church, originally a cathedral, was among the first public buildings erected by the East India Company after Kolkata became the effective capital of British India. The flooring of the church is done with stones obtained from different places. Owing to this fact, it is also sometimes referred to as the stone church. Its architecture represents Greek designing. There is a lot to explore in the St. John church of Kolkata, India. For example, the church contains the sculpture of Job Charnock (founder of Kolkata), which is highly artistic. Tipu Sultan Mosque The mosque is a relic of architectural and cultural heritage. People from all sections of society and religions are allowed to visit and take pictures of this historical premise. The building was built in 1832 by Prince Ghulam Mohammed, the youngest son of Tipu Sultan. Nakhoda Mosque Nakhoda Mosque is the largest mosque within the city. Nakhoda mosque is constructed on the lines of Akbar's tomb in Sikandra. Its architecture represents the Indo-Saracenic designing. Paresnath Jain Temple Calcutta Pareshnath Jain temple is a mind-blowing place of worship, the beauty of which is enhanced by mirrors and colored stones. It houses four different temples, out of which the main temple is established in the honor of the 10th Jain Avtaar, Sri Sital Nath Ji. It is a splendid edifice that consists of mirror inlaid pillars and its windows are made from stained glass. Floral designs further adorn the marble flooring. It also has a garden that contains the blocks of glass mosaics and awesome European statues. In a nutshell, it can be said that it's a must visit tourist attraction religious destination.
strTitle: Religion in Kolkata: Temples, Churches & Mosques

strIntroduction: Kolkata has been nicknamed the City of Palaces and also the City of Joy. This is a city with a true blend of modern and traditional old culture. Kolkata’s architecture owes its origins to European styles and tastes imported by the British. The buildings were designed and inspired by the tastes of the English gentleman and the aspiring Bengali Babus. The City of Joy wakes up with the sounds of bells coming out of the rattling of trams, early in the morning, every day. Trams are integral part of heritage of Kolkata. A tram ride is a true Joy ride, and the city is only one in India which boasts of a tram network that gives the city an old charm. The tonga (horse carriage) in the Maidan is probably not the snazziest and fastest way of transport, but if whiling away time is on your wish list, it’s the best you can get. The wind in your face and hair is not something that comes to you easily in Kolkata! In this activity we will visit: Writer’s Building General Post Office BBD Bagh (Dalhousie Sqqaure) Eden Gardens Shaheed Minaar Chowrighee Fort William Park Street Victoria Memorial Birla Planetarium
strTitle: Heritage Walk in the Heart of Kolkata, the City of Joy

strIntroduction: If every monument you’ve ever seen has been through the lens of a camera, if you’ve captured every emotion of the people you love, if the only way you see art is through a photograph, then you’re a Photodiarist and you need to be on this trip! Through our trip to Hampi, we will explore not only this erstwhile capital of the magnificent Vijayanagar Empire, but also the artist within you! With the help of travel photographer and vagabond Prachi Chaphekar, we hope to assist you in finding your own creative expression using a camera as your weapon of choice! Hampi is a land of diverse experiences. Join us in exploring these experiences through bouldering and climbing to the top of mammoth rocks, cycling through the quaint bylanes, jumping into cool, calm lakes, making music by a bonfire and getting lost in the galaxies of stars looking down at us! If this is something that seems interesting to you, give us a shout and block a spot! Disclaimer : This is not a professional photography course. We will not conduct ‘know-your-camera’ sessions. You do not need a fancy camera or much experience. All you need is the urge to create!
strTitle: Hampi: Bouldering, Cycling, Bonfires, Star Gazing and more

strIntroduction: Spend 3 days in The Blue Matsya (The Blue Fish) - a quaint little beach house in a sleepy town near Manipal on the Konkan coast of India. Mornings will be spent observing the waves and theory lessons on surfing and safety. Come evening and that’s when all the real action starts, learn surfing from a few friends at The Shaka Surf Club, they guarantee that in no time you will be standing upright on the surfing board and catching that perfect wave. Believe us when we say so, we have tried, few things match the trill. Late evenings will be spent telling travel tales and marinating your own barbeque around a bonfire.
strTitle: Learn to Ride the Perfect Wave on the Konkan Coast of India

strIntroduction: On this half-day tour we take you to a pottery village on the outskirts of West Delhi, where hundreds of Rajasthani potter families create magic with clay. Appreciate their art, learn about their culture, interact with them, and make pots with them :) The sharp contrast between the urban and rural parts of Delhi is easily visible. Simplicity and contentment within the people, as they go along their daily chores, can not go unnoticed. This experience will give you an insight into villagers’ lives: - how pottery is related to Indian culture - the role of women in the community - problems they face - their customs and superstitions Make a difference! This tour is a great confidence builder for potters because they feel good that many people in the world want to see the work that they do. Nine families are directly benefited through this initiative. Moreover, a sizable amount of profit earned from this tour is contributed to a Village Development Fund, which is used for the overall development of the community. We work with South Asia Foundation, an NGO working for the upliftment of the poor using crafts as a tool.
strTitle: Learn about Pottery & Create Ceramics with Village Craftsmen

strIntroduction: Check in at your quaint grand old mansion, and meet up with our Punjab expert who will be with you through your time in Amritsar as he shares anecdotes and trivia about the people and their culture. Your first stop is the Golden Temple for their early morning service. It is culturally the most significant place of worship for Sikhs and one of the oldest Sikh gurdwaras. The Temple is not just known for its beautiful construction and spiritual richness. It has been renowned for its 'spotless langar' that feeds any and all visitors, Sikh or otherwise, needy or rich, starved or stuffed, with unquestioning largesse... We too partake in the langar after having listened to the gentle gurbani. Your escort will walk you through the kitchens of the Temple and share the significance of 'kaar seva' at the 'langar'. Soon after we take a walk in the old city thru' old bazaars seeing old architectural buildings and frescoes as we soak in the history of this Temple city. We then head to Jallianwalah Bagh - the significance of which will be shared with you. Late lunch at a traditional dhaba. The city is famous for such delicious delights - the soft as sponge Aloo Kulchas, the ubiquitous sarson da saag, makki di roti and Amritsari sweet lassi. We go back to the hotel for some rest before heading out to the Wagah Border. Wagah about 28 kms from Amritsar, is the only road border crossing between India and Pakistan. It's an interesting experience especially at sunset when the 'Retreat' ceremony takes place with the BSF on the Indian side of the border. Time permitting we can visit a border village where you can observe the typical life style of people on both sides of the fence. If the guests are up to it, the night service at the Gurudwara is quite an experience. Dinner will be at our charming hotel. Next day starts with early breakfast and a trip to Goindwal Sahib which is also famously known as the axil of sikhism (sikhi da dhura) as it was the first centre of Sikhism. Then we visit the flambuoyant palace of Maharaja of Kapurthala. Designed by a French architect and built by a local builder - the palace building has a spectacular architecture based on the Palace of Versailles spread over a total area of 200 acres. On the way back, we visit a community where the Nihang Sikhs live. Nihangs were the suicide squads of the Mughal Army and wore blue uniforms. You get to witness their daily chores and martial arts and get an opportunity to interact with them. For more than just a sneak peek into the rich cultural heritage of Punjab. come breakaway.....
strTitle: Visit the Golden Temple, India-Pakistan border, and Amritsar

strIntroduction: Lord Ganesha - the elephant-headed, pot-bellied, mouse-chauffeured son of Lord Shiva and Goddess Parvati is Mumbai's favourite deity. The spirit and energy around the city at the time of the festival marking the birthday of the favoured God is palpable as Mumbaikars of all faiths and races gear up to celebrate their favourite festival. The whole city comes alive as homes get ready and community Sarvajanik pandals (elaborate shamianas serving as temporary temples) are erected to house this guest God and soon serpentine queues get formed as people patiently wait to seek blessings. On the day of Ganesh Chaturthi, the idol is formally installed at home or in the pandal. This is done by a priest who chants mantras, symbolically invoking life into the idol. Along with this ritual various ceremonial offerings are made. These include amongst others, coconut, jaggery, blades of grass, red flowers, and Lord Ganesha's favourite food, the modak, a steamed dumpling made with coconut, jaggery and spices. For the next 10 days, Ganesha enjoys the status of the most favoured guest. On the 11th day He sets off on his journey to his heavenly abode; the Kailas mountain (Also known as Lord Shiva's abode). The idol is taken through the streets in a gaily procession accompanied by much singing and dancing. With resounding chants of "Ganpati Bappa Morya, Pudhachya Varshi Laukar ya" (Salutations to Lord Ganesha, we wish you come early next year!) the idol is immersed water bodies, both sea and lake. This immersion of the idol also symbolises the cycle of creation and dissolution in nature. And true to this cycle, the wait for the next August begins soon enough! Sounds interesting? We meet at a pre-decided venue and proceed to a Maharashtrian household, which has brought the idol home for the festival, and are a part of the traditional aarti and an authentic Maharashtrian meal... A mouth-watering variety on the lines of bharli vangi, koshambir, tondli, poli, amti, modak... come discover what all of these are. If you can keep your eyes open after this wonderful meal, we can hop over to the murtikaars' for a small chat and then round up the trip with a visit to the Sarvajanik Ganesh mandal to see the decorations and attend the evening aarti. The trip ends with a cup of tea and a snack, this time it is the delectable sabudana vada. And we assure, you'll be looking forward to Ganpati's return a lot more than you think.
strTitle: Ganesh Chaturthi: Take Part in a Traditional Indian Festival

strIntroduction: Smack your lips! A breakaway that promises you the sun and the sand and all that and then some more, provides a weekend with a difference. Amidst palm trees and paddy fields, uncover the secrets of the Konkan kitchen. Cook and savor closely guarded traditional recipes in your refreshingly real home stay. Breakaway helps you find some of the not-so-visible delights on a weekend break in Sawantwadi. It is all to do with food! Discover nuggets of Maharashtra’s coastal cuisine. Sundried spices, sun kissed vegetables, an ocean of sea food, and a tradition of cooking as old as time. Wander through the bustling markets of this fertile coastal town. Pick and choose the local produce, and keep your eyes and ears open for family secrets that will unlock recipes that have been handed down generations. Here is your chance to learn about the regional cuisine. Be a part of informal and intimate cooking classes where you will get plenty of individual attention. It is all done in a spirit of fun. You not only get to taste delicious treats such as olya kaju chi bhaji, fansachi bhaji, sengyanchi amti, modak, bhakar, pithla, usal, alu cha vadya, you even get to cook some of it and you take home the recipes. Have a go at traditional Cooking methods, grinding stone, mortar and pestle and all. Turn out modaks, bakhar, pickles and more. Your companions could lend you a hand or can just chill out with a book in any number of cosy corners. You could also follow a cashew trail right from the time it is picked to the time it reaches the stores, ready to eat. A weekend at Sawantwadi is all about rippling paddy fields, lazy days, beautiful food and a laid back ambiance. Enjoy the breakaway. All you need to bring along is your enthusiasm. Fall in love with Sawantwadi and promise to return sooner than you can say “Konkan”.
strTitle: Pick, Savour, Love: Culinary Trail along the Konkan Coast

strIntroduction: Tungnath is the Highest Shiva temple in the world, but heavy winter snows leave it out of reach to most pilgrims. This is when we'll make our pilgrimage, when you don't need to share this place with anybody else. But be warned, it's not easy. We'll have long trekking days in deep snow (but, we can bring snow shoes!) This is in the shadow of the might og Garhwal Himalays, with Mt. Chaukhamba almost always visible. Above the temple is the Chandrashila (moon rock) peak at 4000 meters, and we'll also try to climb to the top of this mountain. A recommended add on is an extra night at the Deorital lake, which is completely surrounded by snow in winters. Accompanying me on the trip will be a local guide, a cook and porters. We'll sleep in tents, and I can also provide warm sleeping bags. This trip will take 7 days.
strTitle: Winter in Tungnath: Trek to the World's Highest Shiva Temple

strIntroduction: Here’s a chance to go back in time almost 350 years....when there was no Mumbai, just one small island of Bombay. In 1661 King Charles II of England married Princess Catherine of Braganza. The marriage dowry gave to the English the island of Bombay which the Portuguese had no use for. Charles himself didn’t care two hoots for the island. But it was the British East India Company that realised the importance of Bombay’s perfect natural harbour. Deep enough to accommodate 150 ships and with a natural fortification in the form of mainland India, Bombay was perfect for the company’s operations. And so with the Company renting the islands from the Crown, for £10/- annually, Bombay’s illustrious history began. Walk along the periphery of the ‘front’ bay and re-chart the birth of Mumbai. This walk through Apollo Gate and Front Bay covers the northern part of the old ‘Fort’. This was the area where the first signs of habitation were seen on the island of Bombay. The walk begins in the European Renaissance style Ballard Estate business district with its perfect avenues and streets echoing reminiscent of Victorian London. See the famous Town Hall which houses the Asiatic Society Library of Mumbai and the Horniman Circle Garden and the spectacular surrounding buildings. Walk down to the Flora Fountain circle which in some very peculiar ways resembles London’s Piccadilly Circus. Walk past the 275 year old Indian Naval Dockyard with its beautiful mural representing the first establishments on the island. Finally end the walk at the world famous Gateway of India and the now legendary Taj Mahal Hotel.
strTitle: Discover the Birthplace of Mumbai: Apollo Gate and Old Fort

strIntroduction: By the 1670s’ the British had firmly established their ownership over the 7 islands. Bombay’s own inhabitants continued to live their lives in peace and harmony with their new foreign friends’. Life for them then was not very different from what it is for the locals of today. The Indian citizens of the British Raj were the traders, the merchants, the fisherman, the cobblers...basically your everyday regular person. Unlike the south this was the area of the Fort dominated by locals. Welcome to Bazzargate! The Northern part of the old ‘Fort’ this is the area that was known to all of Bombay’s(Mumbai) colonial rulers as ‘Black Town’ because of the strength in numbers of local inhabitants. Merchants, Traders, Fishermen, Cobblers, Ironsmiths dominated the scene with their shops. During the first half of the 19th century most of the banking work was done by Hindu Shroffs situated in the Bhora Bazzar Street (Perin Nariman Street).The birthplace of the famed Bombay Bazaar, back then this was the crowded, dense section of the old town, a feature that can be seen even today. The Bazzargate Walk takes you into the heart of local life from the late 1800s’. Explore the bylanes of what once used to be the commercial centre of the original city. Named after one of the three main entry gates of the old fort, this walk begins at Town Hall and covers areas from outside and inside the original British defence establishment. Walk down Mahatma Gandhi Road and get a picturesque view of the regal Bombay Gymkahana, the cricketing battlefield of the British Raj in Bombay. Walk past the beautiful Art Deco Metro Cinema while making your way to Crawford Market buzzing with activity of the oh so many vendors selling their wares. Wander up to the famous J J School of Art campus,the compound of which is famous for being the birthplace of Rudyard Kipling. Finally end the walk at the Gothic masterpieces of F.W.Stevens, the Victoria Terminus and the Municipal Corporation building, standing like silent sentinels carefully watching the city progress right under their noses.
strTitle: Dive into the History of Mumbai's Bazaars

strIntroduction: Experience the history, culture and the frenetic ‘workaholic‘ pace of Aamchee – Our-Mumbai! A city steeped in history, invasions and colonization by the Muslims, Portuguese, British, resulted in a variety of cultural and architecture styles that peacefully co-exist with the indigenous. One area is reputed to have the highest number of churches per sq. km anywhere in the world! A plethora of magnificent buildings in the ‘Fort’ area exudes British fragrance. The Art Deco seafront is a stunning sight for sore eyes! The excellent harbor made it a great port and Indians from every nook and corner came here in search of livelihood – and Mumbai, the City of Dreams, never disappoints ! All kinds of business and work make the city very fast-paced and vibrant, earning it the sobriquet of ‘The City that never sleeps'!
strTitle: Be a tourist: Visit Mumbai's Greatest Sights

strIntroduction: Distance : Delhi-Agra: 225 KM (About Two & Half Hours Journey) Morning: depart for Agra at 7AM: Visit Agra Fort and The Taj Mahal. After lunch & other activities return to Delhi Agra is probably the only city comparable to Delhi in terms of its contemporary history. Agra is one of the most significant earliest cities of India with rich historical and cultural value. The historical fame attached to Agra is greatly attributed to the Mughals rule. It was the capital of Sikandar Lodhi in 1501 from the North Western Frontiers, who discovered this place. Yet, it soon passed into the hands of the mighty Mughals who virtually held the sway for ages. This striking town is situated in the holy branch of Brij Bhoomi (home of Lord Krishna), on the right bank of river Yamuna. In ancient days the city was strengthened with sixteen gates and was considered as one of the powerful cities of India.
strTitle: Day Trip to the Taj Mahal and Agra

strIntroduction: Come learn ceramics! You are welcome whatever your level of prior pottery/ceramics experience! You will interact with me and other professional and experienced teachers who are committed to teaching you this most therapeutic of art forms. In addition to our classic workshop, we are also conducting team building sessions!
strTitle: Learn to Create your own Ceramic Sculpture through Pottery

strIntroduction: Enter the imperial heart of New Delhi! This Raj tour is a truly breath-taking ride down Delhi’s more recent history. Starting from the narrow labyrinthine backlanes of Old Delhi, passing through quaint old ‘socialist-style’ quarters of government employees and almost magically landing in the midst of a spec tacular view of the Presidential Palace and India Gate encircled by spotless clean, tree-lined wide roads – the Raj Tour is a very stimulating and comprehensive catalogue of the lives of people who make this great capital today.
strTitle: The Raj Tour: A Breathtaking Ride of Old and New Delhi

strIntroduction: This is a walk around the bustling heart of Mumbai for an inside look into the work of those who this dependable city depends on. How? By experiencing a day in the hectic life of the washermen of Dhobi Ghaat and the dabbawalas. Our walk is led by Ramanand with whom there is never a dull moment. He makes sure you look at things you wouldn't normally pay attention to, and he knows of all the best eating places few others know. Dhobi Ghaat at Cuffe Parade is unlike any laundry service you have ever seen. Washermen are hard at work beating the dirt out of clothes at stone cubicles, while others hang a kaleidoscope of clothes out to dry on makeshift lines quite ingeniously, without the help of clothes pins. Whether it is two thousand white sheets a day for the Four Seasons Hotel, or the saris of women from high-rises across the city, these dhobis get the job done cheerily and efficiently. You haven't experienced Mumbai if you haven't used its lifeline - its public transport. On this experience, you will enjoy unusual views in double-decker BEST buses and the all-too famous local trains. Feel the sea breeze on your face as you whizz past Marine Drive on your way to Churchgate to meet with the dabbawallas. A word of caution: these guys don't have the time for interviews and photographs. You will just about manage to scramble into their compartment on the train, where the floor is covered by tiffins and lunch packs of every possible shape and size. It's fascinating to see those dabbas carted from one end of the city to the other, and to everywhere in between. The footpath outside Churchgate station serves as a reconnaissance point, where the men in Gandhi topis wade among rows of hundreds of dabbas, and take them to offices where hungry executives wait in earnest for their home cooked meal to arrive each day. Discover a league of Mumbaikars who are as intrinsic to the city as its own soul.
strTitle: Meet the Washermen and Dabbawalas of Mumbai

strIntroduction: Tea tasting is not just about having tea but trying different varieties and then picking the one you like the most. My tea tasting party will include the following - - A short description of the different types of tea available in India - A trial session (in a traditional Indian fashion) of the different kinds of teas that we have spoken of :) - Picking the best one that we like to take home as a souvenir
strTitle: Vikram's Tea Tasting Party

strIntroduction: The trek to Chopta and Chandrashila offers amazing views of the imposing Himalayan range including Trishul, Nanda Devi and Chaukhamba, and is one of the most popular treks among trekking enthusiasts. Chopta is popularly known as the 'Mini Switzerland' in Uttarakhand and Northern India and is situated amidst thick forests of pine, deodar and rhododendrons. The trek route takes one to Tungnath (literal meaning: ‘Lord of the Peaks’) – the highest Hindu temple in the world dedicated to Lord Shiva. Beyond Tungnath is the summit to the Chandrashila peak (it literally means ‘Moon Rock’) – an impressive vantage point that offers 360 degrees panoramic views of the mighty Himalayas. This is a beautiful trek, with difficulty level rated as easy to moderate. DAY 1: Rishikesh – Sari We meet at Rishikesh early in the morning and drive to Sari Village on the Ukhimath-Chopta road in Uttarakhand. We set up camp by evening for an overnight stay and prepare for the next day’s trek. DAY 2: Sari – Deoria Tal (7,900 ft) – Sari After breakfast, we start our trek to Deoria Tal – a heavily wooded emerald lake with lush green surroundings and snow covered mountains in the backdrop. The mighty peaks of Chaukhamba and Neelkanth are reflected in the pristine waters of this lake – it’s a photographer’s delight. The 3km trek is largely uphill through dense forests. The legend is that the Devas bathed in this lake, hence the name. The lake is sometimes believed to be the “Indra Sarovar” referred to in the Puranas. It is also believed that it was the place where Yaksha asked the Pandavas to answer his questions before drinking the water of the lake. After spending some time here, we’ll trek down to Sari for an overnight stay in tents. DAY 3: Sari – Chopta (9,500 ft) In the morning we make our way to Chopta – a small but picturesque hamlet with untouched natural beauty and peace. It is the starting point of the trek to Tungnath. A 12km trek from Sari will get us to Chopta. Once there, we’ll set up camp and explore the surrounding areas in the evening. The campsite at Chopta affords spectacular views of the high snow-clad mountains. DAY 4: Chopta – Tungnath (12,070 ft) – Chandrashila (13,415 ft) – Chopta After an early morning breakfast, and with packed lunches, we start our trek to Tungnath. The 3km long trail takes one through lush green meadows and finally joins a pilgrim trail which goes all the way up to the Tungnath temple – one of the five and the highest Panch Kedar temples located in the mountain range of Tunganath in Rudraprayag district. After a little relaxation and a lunch break here, we’ll push for the Chandrashila summit. It is a short (1km) but rigorous hike to the top. The view from the top is most promising and truly breathtaking – something one will surely remember for a lifetime. Later, we’ll retrace our steps to the campsite in Chopta for an overnight stay in tents. DAY 5: Chopta – Rishikesh In the morning, after breakfast, we wind up camp and drive back to Rishikesh via Rudraprayag and Devprayag.
strTitle: Trekking in the Himalayas: Chopta and Chandrashila

strIntroduction: I would like to take you to places which make this city or I should say country special. Not just the obvious sites that everyone will see in Delhi, from Qutab Minar to Redfort) You will find a temple or a mosque in every 1000 meters range but some have been able to stand out for their uniqueness: ISKON (Temple for Lord Krishna), Chhatarpur Mandir (Temple of Goddess Durga), Bangla Sahib Gurudwara (Religious Temple for Sikhs), Akshardham Temple (God Swaminarayan), Birla Mandir also known as Laxmi Naryan Temple to name a few. We will visit one temple of your choice followed by lunch. Areas to be visited can be tailored to suit your particular interests. I will suggest an itinerary to match your interests and timeframe. I'm looking forward to seeing you in Delhi!
strTitle: Visit an Authentic Temple in Delhi

strIntroduction: Lush green valleys enveloped by snow-capped mountains; retreating glaciers interspersed with flowing streams and cascading waterfalls; an ancient Gurudwara - the highest in the world - adorned by a sacred ‘snow lake’; and of course a carpet of dainty flowers blooming in vibrant colours; such is the splendor of nature and wonder of monsoon that greets you as you trek into the interior of the Garhwal Himalayas. The Valley of Flowers National Park is a UNESCO World Heritage Site, which bursts into a kaleidoscope of colour as the monsoon breathes life into over 300 different species of flowers. At an altitude of 10200 ft to 11200 ft, the months of July and August are ideal to visit the Valley. Hemkunt Sahib - A pilgrimage site surrounded by seven mountain peaks; the star-shaped structure of Hemkunt Sahib Gurudwara, situated on the shores of Hemkunt Lake is of great significance to the Sikh community. Guru Gobind Singh Ji, the 10th Sikh Guru, is said to have meditated here. The activity will include: - Day 1: Travel via a car bus from Delhi to our first base camp in Govindghat, stay overnight here - Day 2: Trek to our second base camp (14 kms) to Ghangaria, stay overnight here - Day 3) Trek to Valley of Flowers (5 kms one way) and spend the entire day in a land of fairies, in the evening we will trek back to Ghangaria and spend the night here - Day 4: Trek to Hemkunt Sahib - the world's highest pilgrimage point (5 kms one way), take a dip in the holy (and icy) waters here, trek back to Ghangaria in the evening - Day 5 - Travel back to Delhi
strTitle: Trek to the Valley of Flowers & Hemkunt Sahib

strIntroduction: Jaipur is the much loved capital of India’s most romantic state, the gateway to the splendour and magic of Rajashan. Majestic forts and palaces dominate the skyline and yet, it is the bazaars within the walls of the old city that create Jaipur’s unique energy. They surge with locals and villagers, not just tourists, enjoying the best shopping in India. So to experience the city as it was meant to be you have to go armed with a shopping list. I will take you to some of the most essential shopping destinations , and some absolutely unknown treasure chests and fabulous craftsmen tucked away deep in the labyrinth of lanes in the bazaars. Observe local artisans in their workshops; jewellers and silversmiths, gold painters and tie dying experts as well as meenakari and kundan artists. Ask me for souvenirs, contemporary craft, heritage jewellery, silver, precious stones, clothes and textiles, art, antiques, rugs... and lots more! Of course, with me ... a readiness to be distracted will help too, to allow the markets to reveal their diversity. A willingness to be importuned and jostled is also helpful ... All in all .. A FABULOUS TIME!!!
strTitle: Shopping Extravaganza in the Bazaars of Jaipur

strIntroduction: Are you a foodie who loves spices that tantalize your taste buds, or simple foods with lots of flavors? Indian Cuisine has been inspired by several religious and cultural choices, and in each state you will find a unique mix of local herbs and spices in food. Our cuisine has extensively evolved with the influence of the Mughal, British, Turks, Portuguese and Delhi Sultanate, over a period of time. I, being a foodie myself, love to experiment with different masalas, suiting everyone’s palate and enjoy teaching cooking immensely. How about cooking something together? I would be glad to offer you special and customized cooking classes wherein together we get to create some delectable delicacies with our masala art, one that can be the pride of any Indian household! Join me in this journey of colorful spices!
strTitle: Learn to cook North Indian Food at a Cooking Class in Delhi
